PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the ordinances of the City of Opelika, Alabama, of a general and permanent nature. As expressed in the Adopting Ordinance, the Code supersedes all such ordinances not included herein or recognized as continuing in force by reference thereto. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the City's 1964 Code, as supplemented through December 2, 1980 and ordinances subsequently adopted by the governing body. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the Comparative Tables appearing in the back of this volume, the reader can locate any section of the 1964 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    Under this system each section is identified with its chapter and, at the same time, new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper places, simply by using the decimal system for amendments. By way of illustration: If new material consisting of three sections that would logically come between Sections 3-1 and 3-2 is desired to be added, such new sections would be numbered 3-1.1, 3-1.2 and 3-1.3, respectively. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 15 and 16 it will be designated as Chapter 15.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject, the next successive number being assigned to the article or division. 
Index 
    The index of the Code has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by municipal officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which he is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this Code is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental service, by which the Code will be kept up-to-date periodically. Upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances, they will be properly edited and the page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to the holders of the Code with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. Each such amendment, when incorporated into the Code, may be cited as a part thereof, as provided in Section 5 of the Adopting Ordinance. 
    The successful maintenance of this Code up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the volume. As revised sheets are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publishers that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    The publication of this Code was under direct supervision of George R. Langford, President, and Roger D. Merriam, Supervising Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
November, 1982 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida 
ORDINANCE NO. 110-82 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code for the City of Opelika, Alabama; Establishing the Same; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing for the Manner of Amending and Supplementing such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective. 
Be It Ordained by the Board of Commissioners of the City of Opelika, Alabama: 
    Section 1. That the Code of Ordinances, consisting of Chapters 1 to 29, each inclusive, is hereby adopted and enacted as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Opelika, Alabama," which Code shall supersede all general and permanent ordinances of the City adopted on or before October 6, 1981, to the extent provided in section 2 hereof. 
    Section 2. That all provisions of such Code shall be in full force and effect from and after January 1, 1983, and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature of the City of Opelika, adopted on final passage on or before October 6, 1981, and not included in such Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are hereby repealed from and after the effective date of such Code. 
    Section 3. That the repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. That any person convicted of a violation of such Code shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-8 thereof, or as provided in any other applicable section of such Code. 
    Section 5. That any and all additions and amendments to such Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the Board of Commissioners to make the same a part of such Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in such Code, so that reference to such Code shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
    Section 6. That in case of the amendment of any section of such Code for which a penalty is not provided, the general penalty, as provided in section 1-8 of such Code shall apply to the section as amended, or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the aforementioned general penalty, is provided in another section in the same chapter, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section so amended, unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein. 
    Section 7. Any ordinance adopted after October 6, 1981, which amends or refers to ordinances which have been codified in such Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to the like provisions of such Code. 
    Section 8. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are, to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed. 
    Section 9. This ordinance and the Code adopted hereby, shall become effective January 1, 1983. 
    ADOPTED BY THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS OF THE CITY OF OPELIKA THIS 16TH DAY OF NOVEMBER, 1982. 
/s/ Guy Thompson 
President of the Board 
of Commissioners 
ATTEST 
/s/ Zane E. Burleson 
City Clerk

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- It should be noted that pursuant to Act. No. 85-195 of 1986 the city changed its government from the commission form to the mayor-council form at a special municipal election held June 24, 1986. References to the "board of commissioners," "commissioners," "commission" or similar terms throughout this Code will be changed to reflect this change of form of government as the pages on which they appear are supplemented and as the context requires. 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Opelika, Alabama," and may be so cited. The Code may also be cited as "Opelika City Code." 
(Code 1964, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Ordinance codification, Code of Ala., § 11-45-7. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances of the city, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless they are inconsistent with the manifest intent of the governing body or the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Bond. When a bond is required, an undertaking in writing shall be sufficient. 
    City. The words "the city" or "this city," shall mean the City of Opelika, in the County of Lee, in the State of Alabama. 
    City clerk. The term "city clerk" shall mean the clerk of Opelika, Alabama, and, unless the context requires otherwise, such persons as he may designate to act on his behalf. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given, or act is done, shall be excluded in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall be included; and if the last day be Sunday or a legal holiday as defined in Section 1-3-8 of the Code of Alabama, that day shall be excluded. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 1-1-4. 
    Corporate limits, corporation limits. Whenever the words "corporate limits," "corporation limits" or "city limits" are used they shall mean the legal boundary of the City of Opelika. 
    County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Lee in the State of Alabama. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department of the city to do some act or make certain inspections it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designates otherwise. 
    Gender. Words importing the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter. 
    Governing body. The term "governing body" shall mean the Council of the City of Opelika, Alabama. Whenever in this Code reference is made to city commission, board of commissioners, commission board of the city, the governing body, or any like term, the same shall be construed to refer to the city council. 
    Health department. The words "the health department" shall mean the board of health of the county. 
    Health officer. The words "the health officer" shall mean the health officer of the county or his duly authorized representative. 
    Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper, proprietor. The words "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. 
    Mayor. The word "mayor" shall mean the mayor of the City of Opelika, Alabama. Whenever in this Code, reference is made to the mayor, president of the board of commissioners, chairman of the board of commissioners, public safety commissioner, public works commissioner, finance commissioner, light and power commissioner, commissioner in charge of a department, appropriate commissioner, or any like term, the same shall be construed to refer to the mayor. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Name of officer. Whenever the name of an officer is given it shall be construed as though the words "of the City of Opelika" were added. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. Words used in the singular shall include the plural and words used in the plural shall include the singular. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Or, and. The word "or" may be read as "and," and the word "and" as "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include not only the owner of the whole, but any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to a firm, partnership, association of persons, organization, any body politic or corporate or any other group acting as a unit, as well as an individual. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" shall include every species of property, except real property. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Premises. Whenever the word "premises" is used it shall mean place or places. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real, personal and mixed property. 
    Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any park, cemetery, school yard or open space adjacent thereto, and all beaches, canals or other waterways. 
    Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Residence. The term "residence" shall be construed to mean the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. 
    Seal. Whenever the word "seal" is used it shall mean the city or corporate seal. 
    Shall. The word "shall" is mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature, subscription. The "signature" or "subscription" of a person shall include a mark when the person cannot write, when his name is written near such mark and is witnessed by a person who writes his own name as a witness. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Alabama. 
    Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace public streets, avenues, boulevards, highways, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, bridges and the approaches thereto and all other public thoroughfares in the city. 
    Tenant, occupant. The words "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or an oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Time. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Week. The word "week" shall be construed to mean seven (7) days. 
    Writing, written. The words "writing" and "written" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1964, § 1-2; Ord. No. 103-89, §§ 1, 2, 1-17-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., Title 1, Ch. 1. 
Sec. 1-3. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or in the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any of the following: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code; 
(2)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness; 
(3)  Any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(4)  Any ordinance or resolution fixing the salary of any city officer or employee; 
(5)  Any right or franchise granted by the city; 
(6)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(7)  Any appropriation ordinance; 
(8)  Any ordinance which, by its own terms, is effective for a stated or limited term; 
(9)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and/or assessments therefor; 
(10)  Any zoning ordinance; 
(11)  Any ordinance amending the zoning map of the city or prescribing or changing the zoning classification of specific property; 
(12)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat, or regulating the same; 
(13)  Any ordinance annexing or deannexing property to or from the city or describing the boundaries of the city; 
(14)  Any ordinance or resolution prescribing or relating to rates or charges to be collected from customers in the city's sewer or electrical systems. 
Sec. 1-4. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance of the city in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 1-5. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of any section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any section, including its catchline, is amended or re-enacted. 
(Code 1964, § 1-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 1-1-14. 
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeal of an ordinance. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1964, § 1-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 1-1-13. 
Sec. 1-7. - Amendments to Code. 
    All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or any way affect this Code, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection, or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from said Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facia evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are re-adopted as a new Code by the governing body. 
    Amendments to any of the sections or subsections of this Code may be made by amending such section or subsection by specific reference to the section number or subsection of this Code as appropriate in the following language: "Section (chapter, article, division or subsection, as appropriate) of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Opelika, Alabama, is hereby amended to read as follows:..." The new provisions shall be set out in full as desired. 
    No section or subsection shall be amended after its passage by providing that designated words be stricken out or that designated words be inserted, or that designated words be stricken out and other words inserted in lieu thereof, but the section or subsection thereof amended shall be set forth in full as amended. 
    In the event a new section or subsection not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "Section (chapter, article, division or subsection, as appropriate) of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Opelika, Alabama, is hereby amended by adding a section (chapter, article, division or subsection, as appropriate) to be numbered _______, which said section (chapter, article, division or subsection, as appropriate) shall read as follows:..." The new section or subsection shall be set out in full as desired. 
    All sections, subsections, articles, chapters, divisions or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, subsection, article, division or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1964, § 1-6; Ord. No. 133-14, § 1, 12-2-14) 
State Law reference- Ordinance, or section or subdivision thereof to be set forth in full as amended, Code of Ala., § 11-45-6. 
Sec. 1-8. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
    Any person committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city or within the police jurisdiction thereof, which is in violation of an ordinance of the city existing or hereafter enacted, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). In addition thereto, any person so convicted may be imprisoned or sentenced to hard labor for the city for a period not exceeding six (6) months, at the discretion of the court trying the case. Provided, however, that no penalty shall consist of a fine or sentence of imprisonment exceeding the maximum fine or sentence of imprisonment established under state law for the commission of substantially similar offenses. The penalty imposed on a corporation shall consist of the fine only, plus costs of court. 
(Code 1964, §§ 1-8, 16A-6(c)) 
Cross reference- Work in lieu of fines, § 17-8; court costs, § 17-10; remission of fines, pardons, etc., § 17-13. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Code of Ala., § 11-45-9. 
Sec. 1-9. - Prosecution where different penalties exist for same offense. 
    In all cases where the same offense may be made punishable, or shall be created by different clauses or sections of ordinances of the city, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense. 
(Code 1964, § 1-9) 
Sec. 1-10. - Enforcement of certain ordinances in police jurisdiction. 
    Ordinances set out in this Code enforcing police or sanitary regulations and prescribing fines and penalties for their violation, shall have full force and effect within the corporate limits of the city and its police jurisdiction. 
(Code 1964, § 1-10) 
State Law reference- Applicability of ordinances to police jurisdiction, Code of Ala., § 11-40-10. 
Sec. 1-11. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code of Ordinances, so far as they are the same as those of the code and ordinances existing at the time of adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1964, § 1-11) 
Sec. 1-12. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if for any reason any part, section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code, or the application thereof to any person or circumstance, is declared to be unconstitutional or invalid by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect the validity of any of the remaining portions of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 1-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 1-1-16. 
Sec. 1-13. - Supplementation of Code-Generally. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the governing body. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _______ to _______" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-14. - Same-Exclusion of special or temporary ordinances. 
    Ordinances hereafter adopted which are not of a general or permanent nature shall be numbered consecutively, authenticated, published and recorded in the book of ordinances, but shall not be prepared for insertion in this Code, nor be deemed a part hereof.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - City seal. 
    The official seal of the city shall be a disc shaped with the words "City of Opelika, Ala." inscribed about the circumference thereof and the words "Corporate Seal" written in the center. The city seal shall be affixed to all conveyances of real estate, contracts with public service corporations, authentication of copies of municipal ordinances, resolutions, minutes, orders, certificates, etc., and all evidences of municipal indebtedness for money borrowed; provided, however, that the nonuse of the city seal shall not invalidate any transaction with or contract of the city. The city clerk shall have the care and custody of the city seal. 
(Code 1964, § 2-2) 
State Law reference- Seal generally, Code of Ala., §§ 11-40-1, 11-40-2, 11-43-100. 
Sec. 2-2. - Appointment of committees. 
    The president of the council shall appoint the following committees: 
(1)  The executive, finance and ordinance committee to consist of the president of the council as chairman and four (4) council members. 
(2)  The committee on police to consist of two (2) members of the council. 
(3)  The committee on fire department to consist of two (2) members of the council. 
(4)  The committee on public works to consist of two (2) members of the council. 
(5)  The committee on water to consist of two (2) members of the council. 
(6)  The committee on parks and recreation to consist of two (2) members of the council. 
(7)  The committee on schools, library and hospitals to consist of two (2) members of the council. 
(8)  The committee on light and power to consist of two (2) members of the council. 
(9)  The airport committee to consist of two (2) members of the council. 
(Ord. No. 117-87, § 1, 6-16-87) 
Cross reference- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of § 1, of Ord. No. 117-87, adopted June 16, 1987, have been codified herein as a new § 2-2. 
Sec. 2-3. - Investment of surplus municipal funds. 
(a)  Depositories. All bank depositories shall be designated and approved by the city council. Each depository shall be required to furnish the city treasurer with its annual financial statement. 
(b)  Investments. Any municipal funds not presently needed for other purposes may be invested in any of the following: 
(1)  U.S. dollar-denominated deposit account and certificates of deposit with banks or savings institutions organized under the laws of the United States or State of Alabama in amounts which are fully insured to the holder by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation (insured deposits), and in amounts in excess of the insured deposits; provided, that all amounts in excess of the insured deposit shall be secured at all times by a perfected lien or security interest in pledged collateral in accordance with the provisions of paragraph (c) hereof. All municipal funds shall be deposited in financial institutions located within the State of Alabama. 
(2)  United States Treasury Notes. 
(3)  U.S. Treasury Bonds. 
(4)  Certificates of Account Registry Service (CDARS) placed with a local CDARS member. CDARS are fully insured as to principle and interest that may be accrued by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) or the National Credit Union Association (NCUA). 
(c)  Pledged collateral. Pledged collateral for city deposits in excess of amounts which are fully insured to the holder by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation ("insured deposits") shall be secured at all times by a perfected lien or security interest in pledged collateral of the same type and with the same limitations as may be pledged to secure deposits of the State of Alabama. The pledged collateral shall be deposited exclusively for the purpose of such pledge with and held by a trust department of a bank organized under the laws of this state or under the laws of the United States having their principal place of business in this state which may be the same bank as holds the deposit, or a federal reserve bank or branch thereof or a federal home loan bank serving savings institutions located in this state or deposited for safekeeping with any third party bank, trust company or savings and loan association organized either under the laws of the State of Alabama or the United States having their principal place of business in this state. All securities so deposited as pledged collateral shall be accepted at market or par value determined at the discretion of the city treasurer. The city treasurer is authorized to disapprove any security offered or pledged as collateral. 
(1)  Obligations of the Federal National Mortgage Association, Federal Home Loan Banks and of the Federal Farm Credit System. 
(2)  Bonds of the State of Alabama, bonds of any county in Alabama, and general obligation bonds of any municipal corporation of the State of Alabama. 
(3)  Any bonds or other obligations of any state of the United States of America or any agency, instrumentality or local government unit of any such state: 
a.  Which are not callable at the option of the obligor prior to maturity or as to which irrevocable notice has been given by the obligor to call on the date specified in the notice; 
b.  Which are fully secured as to principal and interest and redemption premium, if any, by a fund consisting only of cash or direct obligations to the Department of Treasury of the United States of America, which fund may be applied only to the payment of such principal of and interest and redemption premium, if any, on such bonds or other obligations on the maturity date or dates thereof or the specified redemption date or dates pursuant to such irrevocable instructions, as appropriate; 
c.  Which fund is sufficient, as verified by an independent certified public accountant, to pay principal of and interest and redemption, if any, on the bonds or other obligations described in this paragraph on the maturity date or dates thereof or on the redemption date or dates specified in the irrevocable instructions referred to in subsection a. of this paragraph, as appropriate; and 
d.  Which are rated, based on the escrow, in the highest rating category of Standard and Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service, Inc., or any successor thereto. 
    The pledged collateral shall be deposited exclusively for the purpose of such pledge with and held by a trust department of a bank organized under the laws of this state or under the laws of the United States having their principal place of business in this state, or a Federal Reserve Bank or branch thereof located in this state or a Federal Home Loan Bank serving savings institutions located in this state. The pledged collateral shall be deposited exclusively for the purpose of such pledge and shall have a market value taking into account any accrued interest thereof which is not less than the principal of and the then-accrued interest on the deposit accounts required to be secured thereby. 
(d)  Duties of city treasurer. Investments of municipal funds shall be made by the city treasurer. The treasurer may at any time sell such obligations purchased pursuant to this section, and the money received from such sale and the interest and profits from such investment shall be credited to the fund from which the investment was made. Any such obligation may be deposited for safe keeping with any approved bank, trust company or savings and loan association organized under the laws of the State of Alabama or the United States; provided, that such depository is located within the State of Alabama. In addition to his other duties, the city treasurer shall: 
(1)  Insure that all municipal funds are invested only in authorized obligations and deposit accounts. 
(2)  Keep proper records to demonstrate that all deposit accounts and certificates of deposit are secured at all times by a perfected lien or security interest in the pledged collateral and in accordance with the provisions of paragraph (c) of this section. 
(3)  Report to the city council the failure of any depository to secure deposit accounts or certificates of deposit as required by the provisions of the section. 
(e)  Remedies for noncompliance. Should any depository fail to secure deposit accounts or certificates of deposit as required by this section, such depository shall immediately be removed from the list of approved depositories. The city treasurer shall not deposit or invest any further municipal funds in a noncomplying depository until all municipal funds invested with such financial institution have been fully collaterized and the city treasurer resubmits the name of such financial institution to the city council for reapproval as a depository. 
(Ord. No. 121-89, §§ 1-5, 7-18-89; Ord. No. 109-91, § 1, 5-7-91; Ord. No. 119-17, § 1, 8-1-17) 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of §§ 1-5 of Ord. No. 121-89, adopted and approved July 18, 1989, have been codified, at the editor's discretion, as a new § 2-3. 
Secs. 2-4-2-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Electrical inspector, § 5-41 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-16. - Response of policemen and firemen in emergencies. 
(a)  Each policeman and fireman of the city is hereby authorized and empowered to respond to all emergencies within the city or its police jurisdiction involving endangerment to life or property. This authorization shall apply to off-duty policemen and firemen as well as those policemen and firemen engaged in the active performance of duty. 
(b)  Each policeman or fireman responding to an emergency shall be entitled to all the remunerations, benefits and privileges of office to which he is entitled in the active performance of his official duties. 
(c)  The police chief and the fire chief of the city are hereby authorized to adopt and implement necessary rules and regulations to ensure the proper implementation of this section. No provision herein shall be construed so as to impair the authority of the police chief and fire chief to maintain discipline among their respective departments. 
(Code 1964, § 7-7) 
Sec. 2-17. - Absence of clerk/treasurer; assumption of powers and duties by finance director. 
    Whenever the clerk/treasurer of the City of Opelika shall be absent from his office or shall be unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office, the finance director shall immediately assume the powers and duties of the office as acting clerk/treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 102-82, § 1, 2-16-82) 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of § 1 of Ord. No. 102-82, enacted Feb. 16, 1982, have been codified, at the editor's discretion, as § 2-17. 
Sec. 2-18. - Travel expenses for governing body. 
    Members of the governing body shall be paid for travel outside the city at either the standard mileage rate prescribed by the Internal Revenue Service for travel by privately owned vehicle for business use, plus parking fees, ferry fares, and bridge, road and tunnel tolls or the fares actually charged to such member for travel by air, rail, bus or other common carriers, the actual cost of meals, lodging, and other reasonable and necessary expenses may also be claimed by a member of the governing body as travel expense when such member is away from the city on official municipal business. 
(Ord. No. 112-82, §§ 1, 2, 11-16-82; Ord. No. 104-89, § 1, 1-17-89; Ord. No. 104-92, § 3, 2-4-92) 
Sec. 2-19. - Office of prosecution services. 
(a)  Established; chief prosecutor and assistants. The office of prosecution services is hereby established. There shall be a part-time chief prosecutor of the office of prosecution services and as many part-time assistants as are necessary to carry out the purposes of this office. 
(b)  Duty of office. It shall be the duty of the office of prosecution services to provide prosecutorial services in the municipal court of the City of Opelika. The chief prosecutor or his assistants shall attend each session of the municipal court and remain in the discharge of their duties until the business of the court is disposed of. 
(c)  Qualifications and appointment. Each municipal prosecutor must be licensed to practice law in the state and must be a qualified elector of the state. Each municipal prosecutor shall be appointed by a vote of the majority of the members elected or appointed to the municipal governing body for a term of two (2) years and shall hold office until his successor is appointed and qualified. Each prosecutor shall be eligible for reappointment upon the expiration of his term. The governing body of the city shall fix the salary and conditions of employment of the chief prosecutor and his assistants. If more than one (1) prosecutor is necessary to carry out the purposes of this office, one (1) shall be designated by the governing body as the chief prosecutor. 
(d)  Duty of chief prosecutor. It shall be the duty of the chief municipal prosecutor from time to time to make such suggestions or recommendations to the governing body as may to him seem advisable and proper in reference to the enforcement of city ordinances and laws. 
(Ord. No. 120-83, §§ 1-4, 4-19-83; Ord. No. 126-88, § 1, 11-15-88) 
Cross reference- Municipal court, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 2-20. - Employee work week/cycle; compensable hours, compensatory time and time trading; compensation for certain employees. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection: 
(1)  Administrative personnel. Employees who earn a weekly salary of at least one hundred fifty-five dollars ($155.00) and whose primary duties: 
a.  Consist of nonmanual work directly related to management policies or business operations or administrative work; and 
b.  Involve the exercise of discretion or independent judgment. Additionally, in order to qualify as an administrative employee, an employee must: 
i.  Assist an executive or administrative employee; 
ii.  Perform only general supervision along specialized lines; or 
iii.  Execute specialized assignments under only general supervision. 
(2)  Executive personnel: Employees who earn a salary of at least one hundred fifty-five dollars ($155.00) per week and whose primary duties include: 
a.  Management of a department or subdepartment; 
b.  Supervision of two (2) or more employees; and 
c.  The firing and hiring of employees or the making of recommendations with respect to firing and hiring. 
(3)  Fire protection personnel. Employees who are: 
a.  Employed by the fire department; 
b.  Have been trained and have the legal authority and responsibility to engage in the prevention, control or extinguishment of fires of any kind; and 
c.  Perform activities which are required for, and directly concerned with, the prevention, control or extinguishment of fires, including such incidental nonfire-fighting functions as housekeeping, equipment maintenance, lecturing, attending fire drills and inspecting houses and schools for fire hazard. 
Included are rescue and paramedic personnel who perform an integral part of the city's fire protection activities. Not included are employees of the fire department who engage in such support activities as those performed by dispatchers, maintenance workers, clerks and stenographers. 
(4)  Law enforcement personnel. Employees who: 
a.  Are uniformed or plain-clothed members of the police department who are empowered by statute or ordinance to enforce laws designed to maintain public peace and order and to protect both life and property from accidental or willful injury, and to prevent and detect crimes; 
b.  Have the power of arrest; and 
c.  Are presently undergoing, have undergone or will undergo on-the-job training and/or a course of instruction and study which typically includes physical training, self-defense, firearm proficiency, criminal and civil principles, investigation and law enforcement techniques, community relations, medical aid and ethics. 
Not included as law enforcement personnel are employees who engage in such support activities as those performed by dispatchers, radio operators, apparatus and equipment maintenance and repair workers, janitors, clerks and stenographers, and employees engaged in building repair and maintenance, and culinary services. 
(5)  Overtime rate of pay. Rate of pay calculated by multiplying one and one-half times the employee's "regular rate" of pay. 
(6)  Professional personnel. Employees who earn at least one hundred seventy dollars ($170.00) per week and whose primary duties must consist of: 
a.  Work requiring advanced knowledge of the type required through specialized study; 
b.  Original or creative work involving "artistic endeavor"; or 
c.  Teaching. Additionally, the employee's work must require the exercise of discretion and be intellectual and varied in nature and involve output which cannot be measured on the basis of standardized units of time. 
(7)  Regular rate of pay. The rate per hour paid for normal nonovertime work. 
(b)  Work cycle for general employees. Except for administrative, executive, professional, fire protection and law enforcement personnel the relevant work period shall be the seven-day work week. Employees shall be compensated at his or her overtime rate of pay for hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours in any applicable work week. 
(c)  Work cycle for fire-fighting and law enforcement personnel. The work period for fire-fighting and law enforcement personnel shall be twenty-eight (28) days. Fire-fighting personnel shall be compensated at his or her overtime rate of pay for work in excess of two hundred twelve (212) hours in any applicable twenty-eight-day work period. Law enforcement personnel shall be compensated at his or her overtime rate of pay for work in excess of one hundred seventy-one (171) hours in any applicable twenty-eight-day work period. 
(d)  Compensable hours. Compensable hours of work shall include: 
(1)  All times during which the employee is on duty or on the city's premises; 
(2)  Time spent away from the city's premises under conditions which prevent the employee from using the time for personal activity; and 
(3)  Sleeping and meal time in cases in which the employee is on duty for twenty-four (24) hours or less. 
(e)  Compensatory time. Employees of the city may receive compensatory time off in lieu of overtime compensation only if a written agreement is achieved between the city and the employee prior to the performance of any work which will be treated as compensatory time. No agreement or understanding providing for compensatory time off shall be inconsistent with the requirements of Section 2-49(VIII). 
(f)  Time trading. The practice of "trading time" among employees shall not be permitted unless: 
(1)  The trading of time is done voluntarily by the employees and not at the request of a supervisor; 
(2)  The trade is not made for reasons related to the city's business operation; 
(3)  The city maintains records of all time traded by employees; and 
(4)  The time is traded and paid back within a twelve-month period. 
(g)  Compensation for administrative, executive and professional employees. Administrative, executive and professional employees shall not be eligible for overtime compensation. The governing body shall establish the rate of compensation for all administrative, executive and professional personnel. 
(Ord. No. 108-85, §§ 1-8, 4-2-85; Ord. No. 128-89, § 1, 11-21-89) 
Sec. 2-21. - Indemnification of officers and employees of city. 
(a)  The city hereby indemnifies and agrees to hold harmless all board members, elected and appointed officials, and employees of the city, and their successors, from and against all actions, causes of action, claims, demands, damages, losses and expenses of any kind, including court cost and attorneys' fees, which may be asserted against, or suffered by, such board members, officials, both elected and appointed, and employees arising out of, or in connection with the performance of, or failure to perform, their official duties for the city when acting within the general scope of their authority as such officials, board members and employees, and within the general scope of the authority of the city, to the extent that such actions, causes of action, claims, demands, damages, losses and expenses are not covered by insurance. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as waiving the city's defense of governmental immunity to it or its employees, officials or board members in any action brought against the city or such employees, officials or board members. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall apply only where the city has been given notice of any actions brought against any employee, official or board member, based upon any action of such employee, official or board member within the line and scope of his authority as such. 
(Ord. No. 120-89, §§ 1-3, 6-20-89) 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of §§ 1-3 of Ord. No. 120-89, enacted June 20, 1989, have been codified by the editor as a new § 2-21. 
Sec. 2-22. - Emergency powers of mayor. 
(a)  The provisions of this section shall be operative only during the existence of a state of emergency, referred to hereafter as "emergency". The existence of such emergency may be proclaimed by the Governor of the State of Alabama pursuant to Section 31-9-8, Code of Alabama, or by resolution [of] the city council if the city council in such resolution finds that a natural disaster of major proportions has actually occurred within the city and that the safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the city require an invocation of the provisions of this section. Any such emergency whether proclaimed by the Governor or by the city council, shall terminate upon the proclamation of the termination thereof by the Governor or the passage by the city council of a resolution terminating such emergency. 
(b)  During such period as such state of emergency exists or continues, the mayor shall have and may exercise the following additional emergency powers: 
(1)  To enforce all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations relating to emergency management and to assume direct operational control of all emergency forces and helpers in the city. 
(2)  To expend funds, make contracts, obtain and distribute equipment, materials and supplies for emergency management purposes. 
(3)  To procure by purchase, lease or other means, construct, store, maintain, renovate or distribute materials and facilities for emergency management without regard to the limitations of any existing ordinance or regulation. 
(4)  To appoint, employ or provide, with or without compensation, rescue teams, auxiliary fire, police and utility personnel and other emergency management workers. 
(5)  To assign and make available for duty all employees, property and equipment of the city. 
(6)  To alter and extend work schedules of all city employees and to authorize and approve overtime compensation for all city employees and temporary workers. 
(7)  To waive procedure and formalities otherwise required by law pertaining to the performance of public work, entering into contracts, the incurring of obligations, the employment of temporary workers, the utilization of volunteer workers, the rental of equipment, the purchase and distribution with and without compensation of supplies, materials and facilities and the appropriation and expenditure of public funds. 
(c)  The mayor shall immediately make public all actions necessary to meet the emergency and shall report to the city council without delay, all contracts he may let to meet the emergency. 
(Ord. No. 129-95, §§ 1-3, 10-7-95) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 129-95, adopted Oct. 7, 1995, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, codification of §§ 1-3 as § 2-23 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Overcharging during emergencies, § 19-320 et seq. 
Secs. 2-23-2-30. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-31. - Personnel policies and procedures manual adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by the City of Opelika a "Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual" as recommended by the Center for Governmental Services of Auburn University, save and except as modified and amended by the city council, said manual being on file in the office of the city clerk of the City of Opelika, and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which Ordinance No. 123-93 shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling and shall be administered uniformly for all employees.

Sec. 2-32. - Badges and/or pistols considered part of retirement benefit to qualified firefighters, law enforcement officers etc. 
(a)  Any person who, at the time of his retirement, is employed by the city as a firefighter or emergency medical technician in the fire department, shall receive, as part of his retirement benefit, without cost to him, his badge. 
(b)  Any person who, at the time of his retirement, is employed by the city as a police officer or other law enforcement officer, shall receive, as part of his retirement benefit, without cost to him, his badge and pistol. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall apply only to those persons who have rendered twenty-five (25) years or more service to the City of Opelika and who are qualified for retirement by standards set forth by the state retirement system. 
(Ord. No. 101-93, §§ 1-3, 1-20-93)

Subdivision 3. - Police Department Policy Manual 

Sec. 2-66. - Standard policy. 
(I) Policy Manual. 
    The policy manual for the Opelika Police Department is established and maintained under the following requirements and conditions. The manual will be of a loose leaf design to accommodate 81/2" × 11" paper. The binder will be a three-ring design with black vinyl cover. The cover will be imprinted with the words "Opelika Police Policy Manual" in gold-colored ink. The manual will consist of the following sections. 
(II) Organization and administration. 
    This section shall contain a copy of the official organizational chart of the department, copies of all classified job descriptions, pay grades of all classified jobs, and duties and responsibilities of all divisions and employees. 
(III) Policy. 
    This section shall contain written copies of all policies as established and adopted by the board of commissioners for the City of Opelika. All employees of the city shall abide by all policies. A policy cannot be changed by anyone except the board of commissioners. 
(IV) Rules and Regulations. 
    This section shall contain written copies of all rules and regulations as established by the chief of police and approved by the public safety commissioner. All employees of the police department shall abide by all rules and regulations. A rule and regulation may only be changed, altered or waived by the chief of police and public safety commissioner. 
(V) General Procedure. 
    This section shall contain written copies of all procedures as established by the chief of police. All employees of the police department shall abide by all general procedures. Any command level officer may alter or waive any general procedure when it deemed to be in the best interest of the department. A written report shall be made to the chief of police justifying any variance from procedure. The variance from procedure shall end as soon as the reason for which variance was made has ended. 
(VI) Division Standard Operating Procedure (SOP). 
    This section shall contain written copies of all procedures as established by a division commander and approved by the chief of police. All employees of a division shall abide by the division SOP issued for that division. Any supervisor in a division may alter or waive any division SOP when it is deemed to be in the best interest of the division. A written report shall be made to the division commander justifying any variance. The variance from division SOP shall end as soon as the reason for which variance was made has ended. Division SOP shall not conflict with policy, rules and regulations or general procedure. 
(VII) Form Procedure. 
    This section shall contain copies and written instructions for the proper completion of all forms in use by the Opelika Police Department. 
(A)  The policy manuals shall be numbered and issued to each full-time employee of the department. Each employee shall have total responsibility for his manual and, at no time, will he loan or release any part of the manual to anyone outside the employment of the Opelika Police Department. 
(B)  Upon separation from the department, an employee's final payroll check shall be held until the policy manual is returned to the department. 
(Ord. No. 118-84, § 2(14.1-14.7), 11-20-84) 
Sec. 2-67. - General orders. 
(I) Cooperation with Other Agencies. 
    Sworn members and civilian employees shall cooperate with all law enforcement agencies, other city departments, and public service organizations and shall give aid and information as such organizations may be entitled to receive consistent with departmental policies. All press releases will come from the chief of police, division commanders or their designees. 
(II) Residence and Telephone. 
    Members of the department may reside where reasonable access to duty and obligation may be accomplished without undue loss of time as determined by the chief of police. All sworn and civilian members must maintain a telephone at their residence. 
(III) Change of Address, Telephone Numbers, and Next of Kin. 
    Each sworn and civilian employee of the department shall notify the office of the chief of police of any change in his/her address, telephone number, and next of kin on the proper form and shall report the same in writing within twenty-four (24) hours of such occurrence. 
(IV) Debts and Bankruptcy. 
    Sworn members and civilian employees of the department shall pay all legal debts. 
(V) Badge and Police Credentials. 
    Sworn members and civilian employees shall not use another's nor loan their badge or official police credentials without the permission of a command officer. They shall not knowingly commit any person, not a member of the department, to use an Opelika Police Department badge or official credential at any time. 
(VI) Personal Advertising. 
    Sworn members or civilian employees shall not permit the use of their photograph or name for advertising purposes or by testimonial recommendation or by other means participate in any advertising scheme or enterprise related to or based upon their employment without the expressed, written permission of the chief of police. 
(VII) Outside Assistance with Personal Consideration. 
    Sworn members or civilian employees of the department shall not request nor solicit the aid of any person outside the department in transferring from one assignment to another or in being restored to any assignment from which they have been removed or in being promoted to higher rank within the service. They shall not knowingly permit any petitions to be prepared or presented by any citizen in their behalf requesting such transfer, appointment or promotion. 
(VIII) Gifts, Rewards and Solicitations. 
    No sworn member or civilian employee shall for himself/herself or another solicit or accept gifts, gratuities or compensation for services performed in the line of duty other than pay by the city or as provided in departmental orders unless otherwise authorized by the chief of police. 
(IX) Correspondence. 
    Sworn members or civilian employees of the department shall not enter into official departmental correspondence over his/her signature nor shall he/she convey official communications outside of the department by telephone or any other means except by expressed permission of his/her supervising officer or division commander. All written communications of any nature with any party or agency outside the department shall be cleared and forwarded through the office of the chief of police and over his signature. Any exception to this rule must be with the expressed permission of the chief of police. 
(X) Attorneys and Bail Bond, Recommending. 
    No sworn member or civilian employee of the department shall recommend directly or indirectly to any prisoner or other persons the employment of any attorney or suggest the name of any bail bondsman. 
(XI) Members Posting Bail. 
    Members of the police department shall not post bail for any person held under arrest except at the discretion of the chief of police. 
(XII) Court Cases. 
    Sworn or civilian employees of the department shall not take part or be concerned either directly or indirectly in making or negotiating any compromise or arrangement for any criminal or other person to escape the penalty of the law. They shall not seek to obtain continuance of any trial in court or for any nolle pros or other disposition of any case out of friendship for any person concerned or otherwise interfere with the works of justice. Any member having knowledge concerning such compromise or arrangement and failing to inform his supervising officer shall be subject to disciplinary action. 
(XIII) Civil Cases and Processes. 
    Members of the department shall not serve civil processes nor shall they render assistance in civil cases except when in the line of duty or when the City of Opelika is a party. They shall, however, prevent breaches of the peace and quell disturbances growing out of such matters and take persons breaking the peace into custody as necessary. Sworn members and civilian employees shall not participate or testify in civil cases unless summoned to do so. No sworn member or civilian employee of the department shall be a principal or party to any civil action without written notification to the office of the chief of police prior to the filing of such action. Any sworn member or civilian employee being served with a process concerning civil litigation shall immediately notify the office of the chief of police. 
(XIV) Religious, Racial, or Political Discussions. 
    Sworn members or civilian employees of the department shall not engage in political or religious discussions to the detriment of discipline. They shall not speak slightingly of the nationality, color or religion of any person. 
(XV) Political Solicitations. 
    Sworn members or civilian employees of the department shall not solicit or make contributions in money or any other manner directly or indirectly on any pretext to any persons, committees or associates for any local political race nor shall they interfere or use the influence of their office for any local political issue. 
(XVI) Organization Membership. 
    Sworn or civilian employees of the department are prohibited from joining with any organizational or body, the constitution of which embraces provisions or philosophies of striking or work slowdowns to obtain goals in the police service nor will any sworn member or civilian employee participate in any picket line or take an active part in any demonstration activities. 
(XVII) Untruthfulness. 
    Untruthfulness is a grave disqualification for the police service. Sworn members and civilian employees are required to speak the truth at all times and under all circumstances either under oath or otherwise. In cases where they are not allowed by rules and regulations of the service to divulge facts within their knowledge, they shall say nothing. Failure to comply with the above shall subject the offending employee to disciplinary action. 
(XVIII) Gambling. 
    No games of chance for stakes or other gambling shall be conducted in any police building area. No games of chance for stakes, card playing or other gambling shall be conducted by any employee in violation of Alabama State Law or ordinances of the City of Opelika. 
(XIX) Posting Advertising. 
    No sworn member or civilian employee shall post upon the walls or windows of the department building any calendar, poster, picture, advertisement, or other matter except those relating to or essential for police purposes without the approval of the chief of police. 
(XX) Use of Departmental Property, Stationery. 
    Departmental stationery shall not be used for personal correspondence nor shall any departmental property whatsoever be used for private purposes without permission of the chief of police. 
(XXI) Criticism of Orders. 
    Sworn members or civilian employees of the department shall not under any circumstances or any manner whatsoever speak critically or derogatorily to other members or employees of the department or to any person outside the department regarding orders or instructions issued by supervising officers. In the case where there is a sound reason to believe that such orders or instructions are inconsistent or unjust, it is the right and duty of any sworn member or civilian employee to appeal to a higher authority in the department. 
(XXII) Communications Obligations. 
    Members on active duty or when officially on-call shall be directly available by approved communications or shall keep their office headquarters or supervising officer informed of the means by which they may be reached when not immediately available. Any member failing to respond when called by radio and who is not officially checked out may be subject to disciplinary action. 
(XXIII) Respect to Supervisory Officer and Associates. 
    Sworn members and civilian employees of the department shall treat their supervising officers with respect due the office. Their demeanor towards their associates and department shall be courteous and considerate. They shall guard against envy, jealousy or other unfriendly feelings and refrain from all communications to the discredit of an associate except to their supervising officers when it is their duty to inform of neglect or disobedience of orders that may command their attention. 
(XXIV) Obedience (Ranking Officer). 
    All members of the department shall obey the lawful orders of a ranking officer at all times. Should an order conflict with any orders given previously by another ranking officer or any department order, the member to whom such order is given shall respectfully call attention to the conflict. If the ranking officer giving such an order does not change it to eliminate the conflict, the order shall stand and the responsibility shall remain with the ranking officer. 
(XXV) Department Property. 
    Sworn members and civilian employees of the department shall be responsible for the good care of departmental property, whether fixed or movable, assigned to their care or keeping. They shall promptly report to their supervising officer the loss of, damage to, or unserviceable condition of such property. Roughness or carelessness in the handling of such property shall not be tolerated and shall be made the subject of report by the supervising officer who shall be responsible for the strict enforcement of this rule. 
(XXVI) Deportment. 
    Sworn members or civilian employees whether on active or rest duty shall be governed by ordinary and reasonable rules or good conduct and behavior and shall not commit any act or become involved in any discussion bringing reproach or discredit upon the department. 
(XXVII) Deportment, Ranking Officers. 
    Ranking officers shall by example demonstrate and instruct their subordinates in proper deportment and desirable attitudes in their dealings with the public. Authority in the department shall be exercised with kindness and firmness to the end that justice is accomplished. Supervising officers shall sustain their subordinates when they can do so consistently and avoid, as far as circumstances warrant, censoring them in the presence of others. Supervisors are forbidden to injure or discredit those under their authority by tyrannical or capricious conduct or language. 
(XXVIII) Knowledge of Laws. 
    Members of the department shall familiarize themselves with the statutes, laws, ordinances and regulations in force in the City of Opelika and the State of Alabama, as well as all applicable federal laws. Failure to take action consistent with departmental policy as related to such violations which come to their attention or about which they have knowledge will be deemed neglect of duty. 
(XXIX) Courtesy. 
    Courtesy toward the public is demanded of all sworn members and civilian employees of the department, and any conduct to the contrary shall not be tolerated. Sworn members and civilian employees in their conduct shall be quiet, civil and orderly, and shall at all times be attentive in the discharge of their duties, controlling their tempers, and exercising the utmost patience and discretion. They must at all times and under all conditions refrain from using coarse, violent, profane, or insolent language. When required to do so, they must act with firmness and sufficient energy to perform their duties and shall always be respectful toward each other. 
(XXX) Cowardice. 
    Sworn members of the department are required to dispatch and discharge their duties with coolness and firmness. In time of extreme peril, they shall act together and assist and protect each other in the restoration of peace and order. Whoever shrinks from danger or responsibility shall be deemed guilty of cowardice and gross neglect of duty and unworthy of a place in the service. 
(XXXI) Public Information Request. 
    Any sworn member or civilian employee of the department shall give proper information carefully, courteously, and accurately upon request. They shall avoid all unnecessary conversation or controversy and shall give his/her name and identification number, if any, in a courteous manner to any person who may request it. 
(XXXII) Loitering on Active Duty. 
    Sleeping, idling or loitering while on duty shall be considered a dereliction of duty. Sworn members or civilian employees on active duty shall not read newspapers, periodicals, or similar material in public except in connection with official duties. Any sworn member or civilian employee of the department in violation shall be subject to charges of neglect of duty. 
(XXXIII) Complaints on Officers Employed by Other Law Enforcement Agencies. 
    Complaints of improprieties or misconduct by sworn members or civilian employees from other departments will be routed to the office of the chief of police. This includes complaints from members of the Opelika Police Department or from any citizen. 
(XXXIV) Penalties for Violations. 
    Sworn members and civilian employees found guilty of any violation of these rules and regulations or convicted of a misdemeanor may be dismissed from the department or suffer such disciplinary action as department rules and regulations may direct. Any sworn member or civilian employee of the department convicted of a felony shall be dismissed from the department. 
(Ord. No. 118-84, § 2(15.1-15.34), 11-20-84) 
Sec. 2-68. - Charges resulting in dismissal or disciplinary action. 
(I) Types of Disciplinary Action. 
    Any sworn member of civilian employee of the department is subject to discipline by the chief of police and to dismissal, demotion or suspension by the chief of police for committing any of the following offenses. 
(1)  Commission of a felony or misdemeanor under any statute or ordinance. 
(2)  Illegal use of narcotics or drugs. 
(3)  Using intoxicants in violation of departmental rules and regulations. 
(4)  Neglect of duty. 
(5)  Absence from duty without leave. 
(6)  Neglect or disobedience of any order or failure to comply with departmental rules and regulations. 
(7)  Conduct unbecoming an officer either while on or off duty detrimental to the service. 
(8)  Cowardice, insubordination or disrespect towards a superior officer. Disrespect toward any fellow officer. 
(9)  Overbearing, oppressive or tyrannical conduct in discharge of duty. 
(10)  Incapacity for duty either mental, physical or educational. 
(11)  Inefficiency and incompetency. 
(12)  Breach of discipline. 
(13)  Falsification of records, reports or communication. 
(14)  Criticizing departmental orders. 
(15)  Outside the services communication of information relative to police work without permission. 
(16)  Immorality. 
(17)  Discourtesy or insolence. 
(18)  Untruthfulness. 
(19)  Sleeping while on duty. 
(20)  Uncleanliness in person or dress. 
(21)  Accepting or soliciting a bribe. 
(22)  Keeping fee, gift or reward. 
(23)  Engaging in local politics. 
(24)  Feigning sickness or injury to escape duty. 
(25)  Rough or careless handling of city property. 
(26)  Refusing to give name and identification number when requested. 
(27)  Failure to make proper reports as required. 
(28)  Neglect or refusal to pay just debts. 
(29)  Willful mistreatment of prisoners. 
(30)  Appropriating any lost, found, stolen, department or evidence property to his/her own use. 
(31)  An attempt to induce any officer or employee of the city to commit an illegal at in violation of any lawful and reasonable department regulation. 
(32)  Being a subversive person. 
(33)  Being involved in any work slowdown or any strike. 
(34)  Any other act or omission contrary to good order and discipline or constituting a violation of any other provisions of the policies, rules and regulations, or procedures of the city or of the department or of any departmental order. 
(Ord. No. 118-84, § 2(16.1), 11-20-84) 
Sec. 2-69. - Suspension from duty. 
(I) Suspension. 
    Whenever it is deemed necessary for the reason of any violation of any law, policy, rule and regulation or procedure of the department and the preservation of good order, efficiency and discipline, any supervising officer may relieve from duty, pending formal charges, any subordinate sworn member or civilian employee of the department until same can be reported in the manner prescribed to the chief of police and by him approved and confirmed. However, no member with the rank of lieutenant or higher will be relieved from duty other than by the chief of police except in case of an emergency when a lieutenant or higher may be relieved from duty by any command level officer. 
(A)  In every case of suspension, the supervising officer ordering same shall as soon as practical notify the chief of police in writing stating the name of the accused, effective date and time of relief from duty, the particular rule or law violated, and the specific charges against him together with the names and addresses of all witnesses. 
(B)  Any sworn member or civilian employee of the department so relieved will immediately surrender his badge and identification card to the relieving officer and such property shall be held in the possession of the chief of police pending settlement of the case. 
(C)  Suspended personnel will not wear their uniforms during any period of such relief but shall remain subject to rules and regulations of the department pending reinstatement of dismissal from the service. 
(D)  A suspended sworn member or civilian employee will not be restored to duty pending settlement of the charges for which he was relieved except by direction of the chief of police. 
(E)  A sworn member or civilian employee suspended from duty pending investigation of charges will be suspended with pay. Within three (3) days a due process hearing will be held before the assistant chief of police. Prior to the due process hearing, the assistant chief shall give the employee notice and specification of the charges against him. The hearing shall be conducted informally and the employee shall be afforded the opportunity to present evidence in defense or mitigation of the charges. The assistant chief shall issue his decision in writing within three (3) working days of the hearing. The police officers shall have the right to appeal to a disciplinary review board as provided in Section 2-71. The assistant chief shall ensure that the officer is notified of his/her right of appeal. 
(F)  The chief of police may, for disciplinary purposes, suspend without pay any employee in his department for a length of time as he considers appropriate not to exceed thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 118-84, § 2(17.1), 11-20-84; Ord. No. 134-89, § 2, 12-5-89) 
Sec. 2-70. - Use of alcoholic beverage. 
    Employees of the Opelika Police Department shall under no circumstances drink any intoxicating beverage, liquor, wine or alcohol in any public place, or place of business, to the degree or extent whereby that employee, either willingly or unwillingly, is incapable of exercising good judgement, restraint, or control in their personal behavior, action and conduct. 
(A)  Employees shall not visit, patronize, socialize, frequent or drink alcoholic beverage(s) in any place or business establishment whose primary purpose is for sale of alcoholic beverage and whose source of income is derived therefrom; or those places of business commonly known as bar rooms, honky tonks, juke joints, nightclubs, taverns and such places, except in the line of duty. 
(B)  Employees are encouraged not to drink alcoholic beverages in public places or business, but this policy is not intended to prevent an employee from drinking of an alcoholic beverage when done under prudent circumstances, such as before or after having dinner in a restaurant, and to a limited degree. 
(C)  Employees are expressly forbidden to become intoxicated, appear to be intoxicated, or be intoxicated in any public place or business open to the public. Employees are expressly forbidden to drink any alcoholic beverage while operating a motor vehicle or in public view while a passenger in a motor vehicle. Employees are also expressly forbidden to consume amounts of alcoholic beverages that impair their ability and judgement to safely operate a motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 118-84, § 2(18.1), 11-20-84) 
Sec. 2-71. - Disciplinary action and appeal procedure. 
    The purpose of this section is to establish a due process procedure for disciplinary actions. In addition to the City of Opelika's Personal Grievance Procedures, police officers shall be entitled to a hearing before an internal disciplinary review board. This section addresses the due process requirements relating to all disciplinary proceedings. In the event an officer is charged with a rule violation, the following policies will be observed by all supervisors. If disciplinary actions cannot be resolved informally, an aggrieved officer should follow the appeal process set out below. 
(A)  Disciplinary Action: When a supervisor recommends disciplinary action against an officer of the police department, the incident will be recorded on an appropriate work incident form. The officer will be asked to sign a work incident report indicating that he is aware of the report and the charges contained therein. By signing the report, the officer neither agrees nor disagrees with the substance of the report. Should any officer refuse to sign, a witness (other than the supervisor) should sign to the effect that the refusing officer did see the report. An officer is not required to acknowledge in writing the receipt of an oral reprimand by a supervisor. 
    A corporal, sergeant, lieutenant or captain of police may discipline subordinate personnel for any one violation of an order or departmental policy, rule and regulation, or procedure by oral reprimand (must be documented), written formal warning, or by temporary suspension from duty in accordance with Section 2-69(E). 
    Whenever a supervisor recommends disciplinary action, a work incident report will be forwarded immediately through the chain of command to the division commander for his information and recommendations or concurrence on the proposed disciplinary action. The division commander will forward the work incident report to the assistant chief who will review the report and recommendations and take the appropriate disciplinary action. Upon receipt of a work incident report, the assistant chief will immediately notify the chief of police of the incident and the recommendations of the supervisors. 
    The assistant chief will be responsible for conducting a due process hearing for the officer and taking the appropriate disciplinary action.
