The due process hearing will be conducted in the same manner and in conformity with the same procedures as provided in Section 2-45(VI) for a determination hearing. The assistant chief will ensure that all disciplinary forms are completed, signed and forwarded to the chief of police. If the officer disagrees with the disciplinary action, he/she shall have the right to appeal to a disciplinary review board as provided herein. The assistant chief shall ensure that the officer is notified of his right of appeal. 
(B)  Composition of Disciplinary Review Board: The disciplinary review board will be composed of three (3) members: one (1) member to be appointed by the chief of police; one (1) member appointed by the aggrieved officer; and the third member, who will be the board chairman, to be selected by the two (2) appointed members. The board members shall be sworn police officers of any rank selected from any assignment within the department. 
(C)  Request for Hearing: The board shall be convened by direction of the chief of police after receipt of a written request by the officer for a hearing by the disciplinary review board. The aggrieved officer shall make his/her request for a hearing in writing through his/her division commander to the chief of police no later than five (5) days following the notification by the assistant chief of his decision to impose disciplinary action. In the event the officer fails to request a hearing within five (5) days, the decision to impose disciplinary action will be considered final and the officer will be deemed to have accepted such action. Upon a timely request for a hearing, the chief of police shall, within five (5) days of the receipt of said request, direct a disciplinary review board to be formed in the manner as prescribed in this section. 
(D)  Procedures for Hearings: The disciplinary review board shall hold a hearing within four (4) days of notification by the chief of police of the formation of the board. The assistant chief will give a copy of the original work incident form to the board. 
    Once formed, the disciplinary review board will meet and hear the officer's appeal. In the event the aggrieved officer fails to appear at said hearing, the appeal will be dismissed and the officer shall be deemed to have waived any objections to the imposition of the original disciplinary action. At the request of the officer and for good cause shown, the chief of police may continue and reset any scheduled hearing of the disciplinary review board. 
    The officer shall be afforded the opportunity to be heard in person or by his representative or attorney at the hearing. After the hearing, the disciplinary review board shall issue a written nonbinding recommendation to the chief of police. The board, in its discretion, may recommend to the chief of police that disciplinary action be affirmed or set aside, or that the type or severity of the disciplinary action be modified. Upon receipt and review of the recommendation of the board, the chief of police shall issue his decision in writing regarding the type of disciplinary action, if any, to be taken against the officer. The officer shall have the right to appeal from an adverse decision to a grievance committee as provided in Section 2-46(III)(D). 
    All documents, reports and papers relating to the facts, circumstances, hearings, recommendations and decisions relating to the aggrieved officer shall be placed in his/her departmental personnel file. Copies of all documents shall be furnished to the officer upon request. 
(E)  Termination or Suspension of Employees: An employee who is discharged or suspended without pay for more than five (5) days shall be entitled to a hearing before a grievance committee as provided in Section 2-46(III)(D). The procedure for review by a disciplinary review board shall be in addition to and shall not supersede any officer's right to a hearing before a grievance committee. 
(F)  Forms Used to Document Disciplinary Actions: 
(1)  Employee work incident report (three (3) part, colored) -To be used for commendations, exceptional work performance, or outstanding actions. Use also to recommend the termination of, or to report deficiencies of, a probationary employee. Requires employee's signature. 
(2)  Employee work incident report documentation of oral reprimand -To be used when a supervisor issues an oral reprimand to a subordinate officer. Does not require employee's signature. 
(3)  Employee work incident report for written formal warning -To be used by a supervisor when issuing a written formal warning to a subordinate officer. Requires employee's signature. 
(4)  Notice of disciplinary action and right to disciplinary review board -To be used by supervisors when recommending an employee be temporarily suspended from duty with pay. Supervisors shall make a recommendation for the type action to be taken. Requires employee's signature. 
(5)  Request or waiver for disciplinary review board -This is a two-part form to be completed by the assistant chief for the employee to request or waive a disciplinary review board. Requires employee's signature. 
(6)  Notification of disciplinary review board hearing -To be completed by the chief of police to notify the employee of the time, date and location of the disciplinary review board hearing. Requires employee's signature. 
(7)  Notice of disciplinary action and right to determination hearing -To be completed by the division commander to recommend termination of an employee as a disciplinary action. Requires employee's signature. (This form is not to be used for recommending termination of a recently hired probationary employee.) 
(8)  Receipt of termination notice -To be given to the employee by the assistant chief. Does not require employee's signature. 
(9)  Request for determination hearing -To be given by the assistant chief to the employee for completion requesting a determination hearing before the chief of police and to be returned to the assistant chief by the employee. Requires employee's signature. 
(10)  Notice of possible disciplinary action and determination hearing -To be completed by the assistant chief, signed by the chief of police, and a copy given to the employee. Does not require employee's signature. 
(11)  Employee request to grievance committee -To be given by the assistant chief to the employee for completion should the employee appeal the disciplinary action to the City of Opelika Grievance Committee. Requires employee's signature. 
(12)  Employee grievance to immediate supervisor -To be completed by the employee and submitted to the assistant chief when employee appeals to the City of Opelika Grievance Committee. Requires employee's signature. (This form was prepared by the city personnel department and states immediate supervisor but will be handled by the assistant chief.) 
(13)  Immediate supervisor's answer to employee grievance -To be completed by the immediate supervisor and forwarded through the division commander to the assistant chief. Does not require the employee's signature. 
(14)  Department head's answer to employee grievance -To be completed by the chief of police and copies given to the employee and the City of Opelika Grievance Committee. Does not require employee's signature. 
(Ord. No. 118-84, § 2(19.1), 11-20-84; Ord. No. 134-89, § 3, 12-5-89) 
Secs. 2-72-2-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-86. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The city attorney shall discharge the duties imposed and exercise the powers conferred upon the office by statute and the laws and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 2-20) 
Sec. 2-87. - Compensation. 
    The city attorney shall receive such salary as may be provided by the governing body which shall include all legal services rendered to the city by such city attorney. 
(Code 1964, § 2-21) 
Sec. 2-88. - Representation of city boards. 
    The city attorney shall represent, as attorney, such city boards as the chairman of the governing body may request, which have been created or may hereafter be created by law, ordinance or resolution of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 2-22) 
Sec. 2-89. - Legal advisor of city officers. 
    The city attorney shall be the legal advisor, on all necessary occasions, of the governing body and other city officers and employees in respect to city business, their official duties and all matters pertaining to the city's welfare, its rights and powers, insofar as they may be affected by the official acts of such officers. 
(Code 1964, § 2-23) 
Sec. 2-90. - Attendance at meetings. 
    The city attorney shall attend such regular, special or call meetings as he may be requested to attend by the chairman of the governing body. When so attending, he shall advise the board or any member thereof upon any legal matters pertaining to the officers or interests of the city, shall prepare such ordinances and resolutions as may be required of him and shall, when requested, advise the governing body as to the legality, reasonableness and constitutionality of legislation pending before the governing body or of enactments already adopted. 
(Code 1964, § 2-24) 
Sec. 2-91. - Preparation of written opinions. 
    The city attorney shall, when requested, in writing by the city clerk or any member of the governing body furnish written opinions or advice to any city official in respect to his official duties, insofar as the city may be affected thereby. 
(Code 1964, § 2-25) 
Sec. 2-92. - Representation of city in litigation. 
    In all suits or proceedings wherever pending, to which the city shall be a party, plaintiff or defendant, it shall be the duty of the city attorney to appear for and represent the city. 
(Code 1964, § 2-27) 
Sec. 2-93. - Appeals from municipal court. 
    It shall be the duty of the city attorney to prosecute all cases appealed from the municipal court. 
(Code 1964, § 2-26) 
Sec. 2-94. - Employment of additional counsel. 
    If the governing body is of the opinion that on account of the gravity and importance of specific court proceedings pending, special counsel should be employed to aid the city attorney, it may employ such counsel and agree with them upon and pay them reasonable compensation. 
(Code 1964, § 2-28) 
Sec. 2-95. - Reimbursement for expenses. 
    Upon presentation of an itemized statement thereof, the governing body shall reimburse the city attorney and special counsel for any items of traveling expense incurred in attendance upon court elsewhere than in the city, or for other legitimate expenses incurred in transacting city business. 
(Code 1964, § 2-29) 
Sec. 2-96. - Drafting, passing on legality of certain instruments. 
    When directed by the governing body or any city officer, the city attorney shall prepare needed contracts, conveyances, ordinances, resolutions and other documents, for use by the city or its officers and shall pass upon the legal sufficiency of all bonds of city officers, contracts and bonds of persons having dealings with the city; provided that the city attorney shall not be obligated to pass on the sufficiency of sureties on bonds. 
(Code 1964, § 2-30) 
Sec. 2-97. - Recommendations to governing body. 
    It shall be the duty of the city attorney from time to time to make such suggestions or recommendations to the governing body as may to him seem advisable and proper in reference to the enforcement, revision or modification of the city laws. 
(Code 1964, § 2-32) 
Secs. 2-98-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY ENGINEER 

Sec. 2-111. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The city engineer shall discharge the duties and exercise the powers conferred upon the office by statute and the laws and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 2-43) 
Sec. 2-112. - Duties as to streets, alleys, other works. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer, when directed by the governing body, to ascertain and fix the grades of any sidewalk, pavement, street, avenue or alley in the city and prepare profiles of same, and to see that all improvements on sidewalks, streets, avenues, alleys or other city works be made in conformity with the lines, grades and plans adopted for the same. 
(Code 1964, § 2-44) 
State Law reference- Supervision of public works by city engineer, Code of Ala., § 11-48-12. 
Sec. 2-113. - Inspection of works and materials. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer to inspect all material furnished to the city. All work done by contractors for the city shall be inspected, estimated and measured by him, and when requested, he shall report such estimate and measurements to the governing body. 
(Code 1964, § 2-45) 
Sec. 2-114. - Preparation of surveys, plats, related matters. 
    The city engineer shall make for the city all necessary surveys, plans, plats, profiles, computations and estimates. 
(Code 1964, § 2-46) 
Sec. 2-115. - Reports to board of commissioners. 
    The city engineer shall make monthly written reports to the governing body, detailing the work done by him and under his direction for the city, with such recommendations as may seem proper to him. He shall also make an annual report showing generally the work done in his department and shall therein make such suggestions in respect to the improvement of the city's thoroughfares, sidewalks, alleys and other city properties as he may think wise. 
(Code 1964, § 2-48) 
Sec. 2-116. - Paving and other improvements; assessments. 
    The city engineer shall make out statements which he shall deliver to the city clerk showing the apportionment of all sidewalk and street pavement or improvement assessments and all other forms of municipal assessments which are chargeable to property holders and shall see that all sidewalk, street, sanitary or other municipal improvement work is done according to contract and specifications. 
(Code 1964, § 2-49) 
Sec. 2-117. - City traffic engineer. 
(a)  Office established; city engineer to serve. There is hereby established the office of city traffic engineer. The city engineer shall serve as the city of traffic engineer and shall have control and supervision of all employees assigned to him by the city commission. 
(b)  Duties. The city traffic engineer shall have the following duties: 
(1)  To place and maintain, or cause to be placed and maintained, traffic-control signs, lights and devices for the direction and the control of traffic within the city. 
(2)  To regulate the timing of traffic signals so as to permit the movement of traffic in an orderly and safe manner. 
(3)  To designate main-traveled or through streets by erecting at the entrance thereto from intersecting streets signs notifying drivers of vehicles to come to a full stop before entering or crossing such designated streets. 
(4)  To cause to be placed, maintained and designated on streets by ordinance as truck routes, signs designating truck routes, along and upon which motor trucks and motor-drawn trailers shall be operated within the corporate limits of the city, and when such signs are to be placed they shall be located on the edge of or so close to the streets and highways so designated as to be visible at all times to persons operating such vehicles. 
(5)  To make studies and recommendations for the control of traffic in the city. 
(6)  To keep or cause to be kept a record of all streets and/or other places where parking restrictions, limitations, regulations, or prohibitions have been imposed by the posting of signs. 
(Ord. No. 122-84, §§ 1, 2, 12-18-84; Ord. No. 115-85, § 1, 8-20-85) 
Secs. 2-118-2-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - PUBLIC SAFETY DIRECTOR[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 113-91, adopted June 18, 1991, was not specifically amendatory of the Code; hence, codification herein as Div. 5, §§ 2-125.1-2-125.5, to Ch. 2, Art. II has been as the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 2-125.1. - Established. 
    The regular full-time position of public safety director is hereby established. The public safety director shall be appointed by the mayor and shall perform his duties under the general supervision of the mayor. The public safety director shall be a merit system employee and shall be afforded every right and benefit given to all other employees who are presently serving in classified positions as designated by the Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual of the city. 
(Ord. No. 113-91, § 1, 6-18-91) 
Sec. 2-125.2. - Duties. 
    Subject only to the general direction of the mayor, the public safety director shall exercise administrative supervision and control over the police, fire and communication divisions of the public safety department. Except as otherwise provided by law, the public safety director shall: 
(1)  Exercise administrative supervision and control over all employees of the public safety department. 
(2)  Prepare and submit a budget for the public safety department to the mayor and be responsible for its administration, monitor budget expenditures and prepare supplemental budgets and financial reports as necessary. 
(3)  Develop, implement and monitor operational and personnel policies for the public safety department. 
(4)  Establish organizational divisions within the public safety department and distribute the work of such divisions. 
(5)  Direct, supervise and monitor the hiring, training, removal, discipline and evaluation of the employees of the public safety department. 
(6)  Ensure that proper personnel policies as prescribed by ordinance, law or regulation or as required by the mayor are consistently followed. 
(7)  Supervise the enforcement of all laws and ordinances within the corporate limits and the police jurisdiction of the city. 
(8)  Identify, prioritize and keep the council and the mayor fully advised as to the financial conditions and needs of the public safety department. 
(9)  Coordinate the operations and affairs of the public safety department with other city, county, state and federal agencies and community organizations. 
(10)  Review and monitor all complaints involving the public safety department and its employees; ensure that all such complaints are fully and fairly investigated. 
(11)  Establish rules, regulations, general procedures and standard operating procedures for the public safety department. 
(12)  Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by ordinance or by resolution of the council. 
(Ord. No. 113-91, § 2, 6-18-91) 
Sec. 2-125.3. - Qualifications. 
    The qualifications for the position of public safety director shall include: 
(1)  A citizen of the United States of America. 
(2)  Three (3) years' experience in the direct supervision of public safety employees at the executive level of management. 
(3)  A proven record of written and verbal communication skills and budget preparation. 
(4)  A combination of administrative and management experience evidencing equivalent competence to execute the duties and responsibilities of the position. 
(5)  The demonstrated ability to employ and utilize modern management practices in the supervision of public safety employees. 
(6)  The demonstrated ability to use resourcefulness and sound judgment in emergencies. 
(7)  The demonstrated ability to lead and direct activities of public safety officers. 
(8)  Demonstrated integrity and moral conduct. 
(9)  The ability to maintain cooperative relationships with other city officials, members of the management staff, council, outside agencies and the public on items relating to departmental activities. 
(10)  Bachelor of Science degree in criminal justice, public administration or related field. However, twelve (12) years of experience in a public safety profession may be substituted for such Bachelor of Science degree, provided the applicant has at least five (5) years' experience in a police or fire department executive or management position. 
(Ord. No. 113-91, § 3, 6-18-91) 
Sec. 2-125.4. - Compensation. 
    The annual compensation for the public safety director is initially set at the sum of forty-nine thousand, four hundred forty dollars ($49,440.00), subject to cost of living and merit increases as provided by the city's personnel ordinances and policies. 
(Ord. No. 113-91, § 4, 6-18-91) 
Sec. 2-125.5. - Elimination of temporary public safety director position. 
    The position of temporary public safety director is hereby abolished, effective upon the appointment of the regular full-time public safety director. It is intended that the temporary public safety director shall continue to serve in such position until the regular full-time public safety director is appointed by the mayor of mayor-council. 
(Ord. No. 113-91, § 5, 6-18-91) 
DIVISION 6. - CITY CLERK/TREASURER 

Sec. 2-125.6. - Establish. 
    The nonclassified position of city clerk/treasurer is hereby established, and said offices of clerk and treasurer shall be consolidated in accordance with the provisions of section 11-43-3, Code of Alabama (1975). The office of city clerk/treasurer shall be filled by the city council at its first regular meeting or as soon thereafter as practicable and such appointee shall hold office until the next general election and shall hold office until the next general election and until his successor is elected and qualified. It is the intent of the council that said appointment shall be filled at the complete discretion of the council without posting, notice or compliance with other selection procedures of the city. 
(Ord. No. 132-96, § 1, 11-5-96) 
Sec. 2-125.7. - Compensation. 
    The salary, compensation and emoluments of the city clerk/treasurer shall be fixed by resolution of the city council and shall not be diminished during the term of office for which he shall have been elected or appointed. The city clerk/treasurer shall not receive for his own use any other fees or other compensation for his services as such officer. 
(Ord. No. 132-96, § 1, 11-5-96; Ord. No. 123-08, § 1, 7-15-08) 
Sec. 2-125.8. - Removal. 
    Any person appointed to the office of city clerk/treasurer may be removed, after a hearing, by a two-thirds vote of all those elected to the council for incompetency, malfeasance, misfeasance or nonfeasance in office and for conduct detrimental to the good order or discipline of the city, including habitual neglect of duty. 
(Ord. No. 132-96, § 1, 11-5-96) 
Sec. 2-125.9. - Duties. 
    The city clerk/treasurer shall attend the meetings of the council and keep a record of its proceedings. He shall have the custody of the rules, ordinances and resolutions of the council and shall keep a record of them when adopted by the council. He shall have custody of the city seal. He shall submit all claims, requisitions and demands against the city to the city council at its next regular meeting for approval, unless already provided for by ordinance or resolution. He shall be the custodian of the funds of the municipality, keeping an accurate record of the funds of the several departments, and shall keep books showing accurately the financial condition of the city. He shall keep a record of all warrants presented for payment and shall pay them when funds are available in the order of their presentation. He shall deposit the public funds of the city in such depositories as authorized by the city council. He shall perform such other duties as may be required of him by the council or by law. The duties and job description for said office are more fully set forth in the job description attached hereto as Exhibit "A". 
(Ord. No. 132-96, § 1, 11-5-96) 
Editor's note- Exhibit "A" is not set out herein but is on file in the office of the city clerk/treasurer. 
ARTICLE III. - FINANCE DEPARTMENT[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and taxation, Ch. 14. 

Sec. 2-126. - Established; functions. 
    There is hereby established for the city a department of finance. The department of finance shall supervise all revenue and accounting functions for the various departments and unincorporated municipal boards of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 2-96) 
Sec. 2-127. - Finance director. 
(a)  There is hereby established the office of finance director. The finance director shall supervise all revenue and accounting functions of the city. The finance director shall perform, but not limited to, the following duties and services under the direction of the city clerk: 
(1)  Supervise the design, implementation and preparation of all budgets for the city, its departments, and unincorporated municipal boards. 
(2)  Analyze, inventory and review monthly statements of revenues and expenses for the city. 
(3)  Administer the city's investment portfolio at the direction of the finance commissioner; render financial opinions when requested by the governing body, and prepare financial reports when requested by the governing body or the city clerk. 
(b)  The finance director is hereby delegated authority to develop and enforce appropriate procedures, rules and regulations for the administration of the department of finance, so long as said procedures, rules and regulations are not inconsistent with any duly enacted ordinance or policy of the governing body, and provided further, that said procedures, rules and regulations are approved and ratified with the governing body prior to their implementation. 
(Code 1964, §§ 2-97, 2-98) 
Sec. 2-128. - Revenue officer. 
(a)  There is hereby established the office of revenue officer. The revenue officer shall perform the following duties and services: 
(1)  Supervise and enforce the collection of all fees and licenses for the city and maintain appropriate records of the collection thereof. 
(2)  Supervise the collection of all taxes for the city and maintain appropriate records for the collection thereof. 
(3)  Prepare monthly statements for the governing body and the city clerk pertaining to the collection of all fees, licenses and taxes due to the city. 
(4)  Review on a continuing basis the city policies, departmental policies, revenue producing ordinances and fee and license schedules; render opinions to the governing body and the city clerk regarding proposed changes to the foregoing; and assist the governing body, finance director and city clerk in all matters relating to licenses, fees and tax revenues. 
(b)  The revenue officer is hereby delegated authority to develop and enforce appropriate procedures, rules and regulations for the administration of the department of revenue, so long as said procedures, rules and regulations are not inconsistent with any duly enacted ordinance or policy of the governing body or any policy promulgated by the finance director; and, provided further, that said procedures, rules and regulations are approved and ratified with the governing body prior to their implementation. 
(Code 1964, §§ 2-99, 2-100) 
Sec. 2-129. - Designation of city depositories; deposit of city funds. 
    The city is hereby directed to deposit all city funds in the depositories designated and constituted by the governing body. 
(Code 1964, § 26-1) 
State Law reference- Authority to designate depository for public money, Code of Ala., § 11-43-122. 
Sec. 2-130. - Collection of assessments for public improvements. 
    The finance director is charged with the duty of collecting all assessments due the city for public improvements for any and all purposes made and fixed by the city. He is authorized to adopt any and all methods employed for the collection of such assessments, including the right of foreclosure of the same and the sale of the abutting property against which such assessments constitute a lien, as prescribed by the laws of this state. 
(Code 1964, § 26-2) 
Sec. 2-131. - Sales for enforcement of lien; duty to bid in name of city. 
    The finance director is hereby authorized, empowered and directed, at all sales by the city for the enforcement of its lien for paving assessments, sewer assessments, and taxes, to bid for and purchase in the name of the city all property so offered for sale, provided the purchase price for such property does not exceed the amount of the debt, interest, charges and costs against the same, it being the purpose and intention of this section that the finance director bid the exact sum of such debt, interest, charges and costs at each of such sales for and in the name of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 26-3) 
Secs. 2-132-2-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Competitive bidding generally, Code of Ala., § 41-16-50 et seq. 

Sec. 2-146. - Compliance. 
(a)  No city officer, agent or employee shall make any purchase of materials, supplies, equipment, merchandise or services for the city except in the manner provided in this article and the statutes of the state; any purchase made contrary to this article or state law shall be null and void. 
(b)  Each city department head shall ensure that all purchases made by his department are in compliance with the provisions of this article, and all implementing guidelines issued by the governing body. 
(Code 1964, §§ 26-6, 26-7) 
Sec. 2-147. - Purchasing agent generally. 
    There is hereby established the office of purchasing agent. The offices of purchasing agent and revenue officer may be consolidated with the approval of the city council. Subject to the administrative direction of the mayor, the purchasing agent is authorized to contract for and make purchases of all supplies, materials, equipment and services required by the city, subject to the following limitations: 
(a)  Budgetary requirements. Neither the mayor, the purchasing agent nor any other officer or employee of the city shall make purchases in the name of the city, on the credit of the city or create any debt or liability against the city, unless the expenditure has been previously authorized by the city council, or unless the funds for such expenditure have been appropriated by the city council, either specifically or in the annual budget of the city. 
(b)  Competitive bidding requirements. All procurements for the city shall be awarded in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Code of Ala. 1975, Titles 39 and 41 (Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 39-1-1 etc., 41-1-1 etc., and in accordance with the provisions of this article. For those types of contracts meeting threshold requirements for competitive bids, invitation for bids shall be issued by the purchasing agent and shall be awarded upon the approval of the city council. 
(c)  Professional services. Any contract for the purpose of procuring professional services as defined by the competitive bid laws of the state, with a value greater than required for competitive bidding, shall be awarded by the city council in the form of a professional services contract. Any such contract with a value less than required for competitive bidding shall be awarded by the purchasing agent. Contracts for professional services as defined in the competitive bid laws of the state are exempt from competitive bidding. 
(d)  Electric and sewer system purchases. The purchase of equipment, supplies or materials needed, used or consumed in the normal and routine operation of the city's municipally owned electric and sanitary sewer systems shall be exempt from competitive bidding provided no part of the operating expenses of said system or systems have, during the current fiscal year, been paid from revenues derived from taxes or from appropriations from the general fund of the city. 
(e)  Small purchases. Contracts for small purchases of one thousand dollars ($1000.00) or less, except that purchases by Opelika Power Services are specifically subject to a limitation of two thousand dollars ($2000.00) or less, may be approved by the mayor, the department heads, division managers or their designees without proposals or quotations. The purchasing agent shall adopt operational procedures to facilitate small purchases. Such operational procedures shall require the proper accounting for funds expended and facilitate an audit of the small purchase made. 
(f)  Motor vehicle repairs. The mayor, department heads, division managers and their designees are hereby authorized to contract for the purchase of automotive repair parts or enter into contracts for repair of motor vehicles for amounts of two thousand dollars ($2000.00) or less without proposals or quotations, subject to the administrative instructions of the mayor. 
(g)  Emergency purchases. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, the purchasing agent may make or authorize others to make emergency procurements of commodities and services. In cases of emergency affecting the public health, safety or convenience, so declared in writing by the purchasing agent, setting forth the nature of the danger to public health, safety or convenience involved in delay, requisitions may be submitted and purchase orders issued for the purchase of materials, services, equipment, supplies, or other personal property to the extent necessary to meet the emergency without public advertisement pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-53; provided, however, that proper documentation and verification of the facts supporting the same shall be submitted to the purchasing agent and approved by the city council. 
(h)  Sole source purchases. A contract may be awarded without competition when the purchasing agent receives in writing a valid justification from the requesting department head/division manager that there is only one source for the required supply or service item or, by the nature of an item, the bid cannot be awarded by competition. Such written justification shall include specific facts which support the conclusion that there is only one source. The purchasing agent shall conduct a good-faith review of available sources and conduct negotiations, as appropriate, as to price, qualifications, delivery and terms. Sole source justifications must receive the approval of the purchasing agent and the mayor. 
(i)  Requisitions and purchase orders. Except as otherwise stated herein, a purchase requisition must be submitted or transmitted to the purchasing agent in order to receive a purchase order to acquire with city funds, materials, equipment, supplies, other personal property, or services. The requisition shall be initiated and properly documented by the requisitioning department head, division manager or their designees and sent to the purchasing agent. All purchases executed by the purchasing agent will be made pursuant to an approved requisition from the department head or division manager whose appropriation is to be charged. Insofar as it is practical, as determined by the purchasing agent, for purchases of one thousand dollars ($1000.00), and two thousand dollars ($2000.00) for Opelika Power Services or more up to the amount required by competitive bids for purchases of materials, supplies, equipment, merchandise or services, and two thousand dollars ($2000.00) or more up to the amount required for competitive bids for purchases of automotive repairs, parts and accessories, competitive prices will be solicited from at least three (3) vendors. Approval shall be made by the purchasing agent to the responsive and responsible vendor offering the lowest quoted price. Such written quotes shall be maintained as public record. 
(j)  Credit card purchases. The mayor may authorize certain officials, officers, employees and municipal board members to use a city credit card to pay work-related expenses. All such purchases shall be made in accordance with all city guidelines and procedures. No purchases of personal items shall be made on city credit cards, even if the intent is to reimburse the city. 
(k)  Responsible bidders/contractors. The city will make awards to responsible bidders or contractors possessing the ability to perform successfully under the terms and conditions of the procurement. Consideration will be given to such matters as the bidder's/contractor's integrity, compliance with public policy, record of past performance, relevant experience, reliability, capacity, facilities, equipment and credit which will assure good-faith performance, technical resources and other necessary essential qualities to assure financial stability and adequate personnel. If a bidder or contractor who otherwise would have been awarded a contract is found non-responsible, a written determination of non-responsibility setting forth the basis of the finding, shall be prepared by the purchasing agent. The failure of a bidder or contractor to supply prompt information in connection with an inquiry with respect to responsibility may be grounds of a determination of non-responsibility with respect to such bidder or contractor. A copy of the determination shall be sent promptly to the non-responsible bidder or contractor. The final determination shall be made part of the contract file and be made a public record. 
(l)  Promulgation of rules and regulations. The purchasing agent, subject to the direction of the mayor, is authorized to promulgate rules, regulations and policies in furtherance of the provisions of this article. 
(m)  Controlling laws. All procurements of goods, materials, equipment, supplies, personal property or services shall comply with all federal, state and local laws, rules and regulations. To the extent this article may conflict with any superseding federal or state law, it shall automatically conform to such federal or state law. 
(Code 1964, § 26-4; Ord. No. 101-88, § 1, 1-5-88; Ord. No. 129-88, § 1, 12-20-88; Ord. No. 121-14, § 1, 8-19-14; Ord. No. 123-17, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 2-148. - Establishment of specifications. 
    The purchasing agent shall have the responsibility for establishing specifications of the equipment, materials, supplies or services to be purchased. He shall consult with the department head of the department concerned; but the determination of the quality of the materials, supplies, equipment, merchandise or services to be purchased shall rest with the purchasing agent. 
(Code 1964, § 26-5) 
Sec. 2-149. - Purchase orders. 
    No purchase, except as stated in Sections 2-147(a) and (b), of materials, supplies, equipment, merchandise or services, regardless of the amount of such purchase, shall be made by the city except by a purchase order issued by the purchasing agent of the city or his designee. A requisition shall be used to initiate the purchasing process. The purchasing agent shall issue requisitions to each department of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 26-6; Ord. No. 129-88, § 2, 12-20-88) 
Secs. 2-150-2-159. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RULES OF PROCEDURE[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Section 21 of Ord. No. 125-86, adopted Nov. 4, 1986, amended Ch. 2, Art. V, by repealing §§ 2-160-2-167, pertaining to the rules of procedure of the governing body, which were derived from Ord. No. 113-82, §§ 1-17, adopted Dec. 7, 1982, and enacted similar provisions which have been included as a new Art. V, §§ 2-160-2-168. 

Sec. 2-160. - Establishment of rules of procedure. 
    The rules of or order of procedure herein contained shall govern deliberations and meetings of the council of the City of Opelika, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 125-86, § 1, 11-4-86) 
Sec. 2-161. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings. Regular meetings of the council shall be held on the first and third Tuesday of each month. In the event any regular meeting date shall fall on an official city holiday, such meeting shall be held on the following Tuesday. All meetings shall convene at 7:00 p.m. in the city council chambers of the Municipal Building, 204 South 7th Street, Opelika, Alabama, and all meetings, regular and special, shall be open to the public. 
(b)  Special meetings. Special meetings may be held at the call of the president of the council by serving notice on each member of the council not less than twenty-four (24) hours before the time set for such special meeting; or special meetings may be held as provided by Section 11-43-50 of the Code of Alabama (1975), whenever two (2) council members or the mayor request in writing that the presiding officer call such meeting. Upon the failure or refusal of the presiding officer to call such meeting when requested, the two (2) council members (or the mayor) making the request shall have the right to call such meeting. 
(Ord. No. 125-86, §§ 2-4, 15, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 113-95, § 1, 5-16-95) 
Sec. 2-162. - Order of business. 
    The order of business shall be as follows: 
(1)  A call to order. 
(2)  Roll call. 
(3)  Invocation. 
(4)  Pledge of allegiance. 
(5)  Reading of the minutes. 
(6)  Unfinished business. 
(7)  Remarks by mayor. 
(8)  Citizens communications (Limit comments to five (5) minutes or less) 
(9)  Report of disbursements. 
(10)  Committee reports. 
(11)  General business. 
(12)  Awarding of bids. 
(13)  Resolutions. 
(14)  Ordinances. 
(15)  Appointments. 
(16)  Adjourn. 
(Ord. No. 125-86, § 6, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 124-88, § 1, 11-1-88; Ord. No. 136-92, § 1, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 108-08, § 1, 2-19-08) 
Sec. 2-163. - Presiding officer. 
(a)  Addressing council; permission and discretion of presiding officer. No person not a member of the council shall be allowed to address the council while in session without permission of the presiding officer. The presiding officer of the council may, at his discretion, call any member to take the chair, to allow him to address the council, make a motion or discuss any other matter at issue. No member of the council shall speak more the twice on the same subject without permission of the presiding officer. 
(b)  Questions of order. All questions of order shall be decided by the presiding officer of the council with the right of appeal to the council by any member. 
(Ord. No. 125-86, §§ 7, 8, 12, 13, 11-4-86) 
Sec. 2-164. - Quorum. 
    Three (3) members of the council shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any and all business to be done by the council. 
(Ord. No. 125-86, § 5, 11-4-86) 
Sec. 2-165. - Records. 
    Whenever it shall be required by one or more members, the "yeas" and the "nays" shall be recorded, and any member may call for a division on any question. 
(Ord. No. 125-86, § 11, 11-4-86) 
Sec. 2-166. - Motions, ordinances and resolutions. 
(a)  Reduction to writing. Motions shall be reduced to writing when required by the presiding officer of the council or any member of the council. All resolutions and ordinances shall be in writing. 
(b)  Order of motions and questions. Motions to lay any matter on the table shall be first in order; and on all questions, the last amendment, the most distant day, and the largest sum shall be first put. 
(c)  Motions for adjournment. A motion for adjournment shall always be in order. 
(d)  Adoption of ordinances and resolutions. No ordinance or resolution of a permanent nature shall be adopted at the meeting at which it is introduced unless unanimous consent be obtained for the immediate consideration of such ordinance or resolution, such consent shall be by roll call and the vote thereon spread on the minutes. No ordinance or resolution of a permanent nature shall be adopted unless on its final passage three (3) members of the council shall vote in its favor. 
(e)  Motions to reconsider. Motions to reconsider shall be by a member who voted with a majority, and at the same or next succeeding meeting of the council. 
(Ord. No. 125-86, §§ 9, 10, 14, 16, 19, 20, 11-4-86) 
Sec. 2-167. - Suspension of rules. 
    The rules of the council may be altered, amended or temporarily suspended by a vote of two-thirds of the members present. 
(Ord. No. 125-86, § 17, 11-4-86) 
Sec. 2-168. - Attendance of meetings by city officers. 
    The clerk, engineer, attorney and department heads and such other officers and employees of the city shall, when requested, attend all meetings of the council and shall remain in the council room for such length of time as the council may direct. 
(Ord. No. 125-86, § 18, 11-4-86) 
Secs. 2-169-2-179. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC SAFETY DEPARTMENT[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 1-4 of Ordinance No. 126-91, adopted Sept. 1991 did not specifically amend the Code; hence, such sections have been included herein as a new Art. VI, §§ 2-180-2-183, at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Public safety director, § 2-125.1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-180. - Established. 
    There is hereby established the department of public safety of the city. 
(Ord. No. 126-91, § 1, 9-17-91) 
Sec. 2-181. - Officers and employees. 
    The public safety department of the city shall consist of a public safety director and such officers and employees as the city council may from time to time designate. 
(Ord. No. 126-91, § 2, 9-17-91) 
Sec. 2-182. - Structure. 
    The public safety department shall consist of the following divisions: 
(1)  Police division. 
(2)  Fire division. 
(3)  Public safety 911 communications. 
(4)  Animal control division. 
(Ord. No. 126-91, § 3, 9-17-91) 
Sec. 2-183. - Public safety director, responsibilities. 
    The public safety director shall be responsible, subject to the general supervision of the mayor, for the enforcement of all departmental regulations and the conduct of the public safety department in accordance with all ordinances and resolutions adopted by the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 126-91, § 4, 9-17-91) 
Cross reference- Duties of public safety director, § 2-125.2. 
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and taxation, Ch. 14; public intoxication, § 19-448; nudity and sexual conduct in establishments dealing in alcoholic beverages, § 19-551 et seq. 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages generally, Code of Ala., § 28-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
    Wherever used in this chapter the following words and phrases shall have the meanings herein specifically ascribed to them: 
    Alcoholic beverages: Any alcoholic, spirituous, vinous, fermented, or other alcoholic beverage, or combination of liquors and mixed liquor, a part of which is spirituous, vinous, fermented, or otherwise alcoholic, and all drinks or drinkable liquids, preparations or mixtures intended for beverage purposes, which contain one-half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume, and shall include liquor, beer and wine, both fortified and table wine. 
    Association: A partnership, limited partnership, or any form of unincorporated enterprise owned by two (2) or more persons. 
    Beer: Any beer, larger beer, ale, porter, malt or brewed beverage or similar fermented malt liquor containing one-half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume and not in excess of four (4) percent alcohol by weight and five (5) percent by volume, by whatever name the same may be called. 
    Board: The Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. 
    Brewpub: An establishment licensed and meeting the qualifications of a brewpub under the state alcoholic beverage control laws, including Code of Ala., Tit. 28 Ch. 4A, and which meets the following additional requirements: 
(1)  The establishment must be located in a building designated as a historic building, located in a historic district, or located in any economically distressed area designated as suitable by the municipal governing body. 
(2)  The beer brewed by the brew pub cannot be possessed, sold or dispensed except on the premises where it is brewed. 
(3)  The establishment cannot produce more than ten thousand (10,000) barrels of beer in one (1) year. 
(4)  The establishment must contain and operate a restaurant licensed under the provisions of section 3-37(e). 
(5)  The serving of food or meals must constitute the principal business of such establishment, with the serving of liquor, malt or brewed beverages, wines and other alcoholic beverages being only an incidental part of the business. During any ninety (90) day period, the gross receipts from the serving of meals and food shall constitute more than fifty (50) percent of the gross receipts of the business. 
(5)  The establishment must be located in a suitable building within an appropriate zoning district. 
    Container: The single bottle, can, keg, bag or other receptacle, not a carton, in which alcoholic beverages are originally packaged for the market by the manufacturer or importer and from which the alcoholic beverage is consumed by or dispensed to the public. 
    Corporation: A corporation or a joint stock association organized under the laws of this state, United States, or any other state, territory or foreign country, or dependency. 
    Engaged in business: A person shall be deemed engaged in business within the corporate limits or its police jurisdiction, if that person has a fixed place of business within said corporate limits, or if, pursuant to agreement of sale, express or implied, that person delivers any alcoholic beverage or liquor, beer or wine within said corporate limits, or if that person performs within said corporate limits, any act authorized to be done only by the holder of any license issued by the board. 
    Fixed place of business: Any place where any alcoholic beverage, liquor, wine or beer is kept or stored for sale or delivery. 
    Fortified wine: Any wine containing more than fourteen (14) percent alcohol by volume but not more than twenty-four (24) percent. 
    Liquor: Any alcoholic, spirituous, vinous, fermented or other alcoholic beverage, or combination of liquors and mixed liquor, a part of which is spirituous, fermented, or vinous or otherwise alcoholic, and all drinks or drinkable liquids, preparations or mixtures intended for beverage purposes, which contain one-half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume except beer. 
    Liquor store: A liquor store operated by the board, where alcoholic beverages other than beer are authorized to be sold in unopened containers. 
    Lounge: There shall be two (2) classes of lounge retail liquor licenses: 
(1)  Class I: Any place or premises in which liquor or wine is offered for sale for consumption within the building in which the establishment is located, which is operated by a responsible person of good reputation, which meets the following additional requirements: 
a.  A space of at least one thousand (1,000) square feet on one (1) floor in one (1) room, accommodating at least thirty (30) persons at one time. 
b.  Such establishment must meet the minimum requirements for an Alabama Alcoholic Beverage and Control On-Premise Lounge Retail Liquor License. 
c.  This class will permit the licensee to sell alcoholic beverages for both on-premise and off-premise consumption. However, all sales for off-premise consumption shall be in original unopened containers. 
(2)  Class II: Any place or premise in which liquor or wine is offered for sale only for off-premise consumption in original unopened containers. There shall be no alcoholic beverages served for on-premise consumption by this class. Such establishment shall meet the minimum requirements for an Alabama Alcoholic Beverage and Control Board Off-Premise Lounge Retail Liquor License, and shall be operated by a responsible person of good reputation. 
    Manufacturer: Any person licensed by the board to produce, manufacture, brew, distill or ferment alcoholic beverages of any nature or description. 
    Person: Every natural person, association or corporation. Whenever used in a clause prescribing or imposing a fine or imprisonment, or both, such term as applied to "association" shall mean the partners or members thereof and as applied to "corporation" shall mean the officers thereof, except as to incorporated clubs the term "person" shall mean such individual or individuals who, under the by-laws of such clubs, shall have jurisdiction over the possession and sale of liquor therein. 
    Private club: A corporation or association organized or formed in good faith by authority of law and which must have at least one hundred fifty (150) paid-up members. It must be the owner, lessee or occupant of an establishment operated solely for the objects of a national, social, patriotic, political or athletic nature or the like, but not for pecuniary gain and the property as well as the advantages of which belong to all the members, and which maintains an establishment provided with special space and accommodations where, in consideration of payment, food with or without lodging is habitually served. The private club shall hold regular meetings, continue its business through officers regularly elected, admit members by written application, investigation and ballot and charge and collect dues from elected members. 
    Restaurant: A reputable place licensed as a restaurant, operated by a responsible person of good reputation, in which a diversified selection of foods, refreshments, and alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption within the building in which the establishment is located, and which meets the following additional requirements: 
(a)  A dining space of at least one thousand (1,000) square feet on one floor in one room, said dining room to be equipped with tables and chairs accommodating at least fifty (50) persons at one time. 
(b)  A kitchen separate and apart from the dining area, but adjoining the same, in which food is prepared for consumption by the public and in which food or meals served in said dining room are prepared. 
(c)  At least one meal per day shall be served at least six (6) days per week, with the exception of holidays, vacations and periods for redecorating. 
(d)  Such place shall meet the minimum requirements for an Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board On-Premises License. 
(e)  The serving of food or meals shall constitute the principal business of such establishment, with the serving of liquor, malt or brewed beverages, wines and other alcoholic beverages being only an incidental part of business. During any ninety-day period, the gross receipts from the serving of meals and food shall constitute more than fifty (50) percent of the gross receipts of the business. The owner or owners of such establishment shall maintain separate cash register receipts, one for food and one for liquor, malt or brewed beverages, wines or other alcoholic beverages. In addition, the owner or owners of such establishment shall maintain all invoices for the purchase of food and liquor and shall preserve such records for not less than two (2) years. All of such records shall be opened for inspection and checking during such regular business hours as the finance director of the city or his duly authorized representative may request. 
    Retailer: Any person licensed by the board to engage in the retail sale of any beverages to the consumer. 
    Sale or sell: Any transfer of liquor, wine or beer for a consideration, and any gift in connection with, or as a part of, a transfer of property other than liquor, wine or beer for a consideration. 
    Special events retail license: A license issued to a responsible organization of good reputation, for a period not to exceed seven (7) days, upon such terms and conditions as the city council may prescribe. The license shall authorize the licensee to sell table wine and beer at retail and dispense such alcoholic beverages as are authorized by the city council to patrons, guests, or members of the organization at such locations or areas as shall be authorized by the city council upon such terms and conditions as prescribed by the city council. Such organization shall also meet the minimum requirements for a special events retail license issued by the board. 
    Special retail more than 30 days: A license issued to a responsible organization of good reputation for a period to exceed more than thirty (30) days upon such terms and conditions as the city council may prescribe. The license shall authorize the licensee to sell table wine, liquor and beer at retail and dispense such alcoholic beverages as are authorized by the city council to patrons, guests or members of the organization at such locations or areas as shall be authorized by the city council upon such terms and conditions as prescribed by the city council. Such organizations shall also meet the minimum requirements for a special retail more than thirty (30) days license issued by the board. 
    Table wine: Any wine containing not more than fourteen (14) percent alcohol by volume. 
    Unopened container: A container containing alcoholic beverages, which has not been opened or unsealed subsequent to filling and sealing by the manufacturer or importer. 
    Wholesaler: Any person licensed by the board to engage in the sale and distribution of table wine and beer or either of them, within this state at wholesale only, to be sold by export or retail licensees or other wholesale licensees or others within this state lawfully authorized to sell table wine and beer, or either of them for the purpose of resale only. 
    Wine: All beverages made from the fermentation of fruits, berries, or grapes, with or without added spirits and produced in accordance with the laws and regulations of the United States, containing not more than twenty-four (24) percent alcohol by volume, and shall include all sparkling wines, carbonated wines, special natural wines, rectified wines, vermouths, vinous beverages, vinous liquors, and like products. 
(Ord. No. 107-81, § 1, 4-21-81; Ord. No. 103-87, § 1, 2-17-87; Ord. No. 116-88, § 1, 7-5-88; Ord. No. 120-99, § 1, 8-17-99; Ord. No. 130-10, § 1, 12-21-10; Ord. No. 117-13, 1, 10-15-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 28-3A-2. 
Sec. 3-2. - Exemption. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to ethyl alcohol intended for use or used for the following purposes: 
(1)  For scientific, chemical, mechanical, industrial, medicinal and culinary purposes; 
(2)  For use by those authorized to procure the same tax-free as provided by acts of congress and regulations promulgated thereunder; 
(3)  In the manufacture of denatured alcohol produced and used as provided by acts of congress and regulations promulgated thereunder; 
(4)  In the manufacture of patented, patent, proprietary, medicinal, pharmaceutical, antiseptic, toilet, scientific, chemical, mechanical and industrial preparations or products unfit for beverage purposes; or 
(5)  In the manufacture of flavoring extracts and syrups unfit for beverage purposes. 
(Code 1964, §§ 3-3, 3-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 28-3-3. 
Sec. 3-3. - Enforcement. 
    The finance department shall administer and enforce this chapter. Such department shall have the power to enter upon the premises of any taxpayer and to examine, or cause to be examined, any books, papers, records or memoranda bearing upon the amount of taxes payable, and to secure other information, directly or indirectly, necessary in the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 3-5) 
Sec. 3-4. - Violations of state regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of any rules and regulations promulgated by the board. 
Sec. 3-5. - Fortifying, adulterating beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful to fortify, adulterate, contaminate or in any way to change the character or purity of any alcoholic beverage regulated under the provisions of this chapter, from that as originally marketed by the manufacturer except for a retail licensee on order from a customer to mix a chaser or other ingredients necessary to prepare a cocktail or mixed drink for on-premises consumption. 
(Code 1964, § 3-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 28-3A-25(a)(10). 
Sec. 3-6. - Consumption in state liquor stores. 
    No alcoholic beverages sold or dispensed by the state liquor store in the city shall be drunk on the premises of such store, and the drinking of the same on such premises is hereby declared to be a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 3-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 28-3A-25(a)(4). 
Sec. 3-7. - Hours and days of sale. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the proprietor, keeper or operator, or the servants, agents or employees of the same, of any cafe, lunchroom, restaurant, hotel, motel, lounge, pub, or any other public place to knowingly permit any person to give away, sell or serve for consumption on or off the premises, or drink or consume any alcoholic beverages on the premises of such cafe, lunchroom, restaurant, hotel, motel, lounge, pub, or other public place between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday or Saturday of any week, or between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon on Sunday of any week, within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any manufacturer, wholesaler or distributor, or the servants, agents or employees of the same to sell, trade or give away any alcoholic beverages between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, or Saturday of any week, or between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon on Sunday of any week, within the city. 
(Code 1964, § 3-15; Ord. No. 120-81, § 1, 11-3-81; Ord. No. 113-90, § 1, 4-3-90; Ord. No. 100-04, § 1, 1-21-04) 
Sec. 3-8. - Sales to minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, furnish or give away, or attempt to sell, furnish or give away, any alcoholic beverages to any person under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(Code 1964, § 3-9, 3-29(c); Ord. No. 108-88, § 1, 5-3-88) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 28-3A-25(a)(3). 
Sec. 3-9. - Possession, consumption, etc., by minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to attempt to purchase, purchase, consume, possess or transport any alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  No person, directly or indirectly, shall falsely represent or attempt to falsely represent that a person is over twenty-one (21) years of age, by means of which false representation he aids or abets, or attempts to aid or abet, such person to buy, receive or otherwise obtain any alcoholic beverages. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit any employee of a wholesale licensee under the Alcoholic Beverage Licensing Code from handling, transporting or selling beer or table wine if such employee is acting within the line and scope of his employment while so acting. 
(Code 1964, § 3-29, 3-30; Ord. No. 102-89, § 1, 1-17-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 28-3A-25(a)(19). 
Sec. 3-10. - Employment of minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to employ any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to sell or dispense alcoholic beverages of any kind. Nothing in this section shall prohibit any employee of a wholesale licensee under the Alcoholic Beverage Licensing Code from handling, transporting or selling beer or table wine if such employee is acting within the line and scope of his employment while so acting. There must be a person over twenty-one (21) years of age present at all times a licensed establishment is open for business. 
(Code 1964, § 3-28; Ord. No. 102-89, § 2, 1-17-89) 
Sec. 3-11. - Electric or painted signs outside alcoholic beverage establishments. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to display any electric or painted sign outside any place of business advertising alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1964, § 3-18) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 28-3-16. 
Sec. 3-12. - Vehicles for delivery of certain beverages; identification prescribed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any manufacturer or wholesaler to deliver any alcoholic beverages except in vehicles bearing the name, address and permit number of such wholesaler or manufacturer, painted or affixed plainly on each side of such vehicle in letters no smaller than four (4) inches in height. 
(Code 1964, § 3-17) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 28-3A-25(a)(13). 
Sec. 3-13. - Sale of malt or brewed beverages in open containers. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law, it shall be unlawful for any person to sell malt or brewed beverages except in sealed containers such as bottles or cans. 
(Code 1964, § 3-31) 
State Law reference- Sale of beer in original containers, at draft, etc., Code of Ala., § 28-3A-23(g). 
Sec. 3-14. - Purchase from unauthorized persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase any alcoholic beverages from any person except those duly authorized and licensed under the provisions of this chapter or under any laws of this state. 
(Code 1964, § 3-21) 
Sec. 3-15. - Possession and consumption in public. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) below, it shall be unlawful for any person to drink or consume alcoholic beverages or possess an open container containing an alcoholic beverage in or on any public place as herein defined. For the purposes of this section, the phrase "public place" shall have the following meaning: 
(1)  Any street, highway, thoroughfare, alley or sidewalk owned by government, either directly or through a public corporation or authority, that is designed for the use, enjoyment or transportation of the general public. 
(2)  Any building with all appurtenances (including grounds and yards), owned or operated by government, either directly or through a public corporation or authority, that is designed for the use or enjoyment of the general public. City hall, libraries, school buildings, auditoriums, courthouses, judiciary building, post offices and public administrative buildings are included within the meaning of the phrase "public place". 
(3)  Any parks, playgrounds, athletic fields, golf courses, tennis courts and recreational facilities owned or operated by government, either directly or through a public corporation or authority, that is designed for the use or enjoyment of the general public, which are not licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(4)  Any place or location used for or in connection with public passenger transportation, whether by air, railroad, motor vehicle or other method, which is not licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(5)  Any place or location, whether public or private, that may be readily seen by normal unaided vision viewing from a public street, highway, sidewalk, thoroughfare, park or other public property. Provided that no private dwelling (including appurtenances, yards, and grounds) and no place engaged for a private gathering is included within the meaning of public place with respect to the owners or occupants of such dwelling or place or to any persons specifically invited therein. 
(6)  Any parking lot that is designed for the use of the general public. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) above, alcoholic beverages may be served and consumed: 
(1)  In the determined boundaries of a sidewalk café approved in accordance with the provisions of Article VII of Chapter 26. 
(2)  In areas of the downtown entertainment district, patrons, guests or members of a licensee may exit a licensed premises in the district with open containers of alcoholic beverages and consume alcoholic beverages anywhere within the confines of the district, but may not enter another licensed premises with open or closed containers of alcoholic beverages. 
(3)  In or upon any premises, including adjacent patios and decks (provided the patio or deck is approved by the board), which have been duly licensed by the city and the board for the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(4)  In or upon any public place or premises for which the city has issued a special event license or outdoor dining permit. 
(5)  During public or private events in public buildings and facilities provided the required city and state alcoholic beverage licenses are obtained. 
(Code 1964, § 3-23; Ord. No. 126-90, § 1, 8-21-90; Ord. No. 120-99, § 2, 8-17-99; Ord. No. 104-10, § 1, 2-16-10; Ord. No. 122-12, § 1, 10-16-12) 
Cross reference- Driving while intoxicated, § 16-52; pedestrians under influence of alcohol, § 16-212; public intoxication, § 19-448. 
Sec. 3-16. - Possession of untaxed liquors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession within the city or its police jurisdiction any alcoholic beverages on which the tax prescribed by this state has not been paid and which does not bear an appropriate stamp showing such payment. This section shall include but is not limited to whiskey usually called "stump-juice," or "wild-cat whiskey," "white lightning" and liquors of like character. 
(Code 1964, § 3-16) 
Sec. 3-17. - Contraband beverages-Generally. 
(a)  All alcoholic beverages and alcohol not stamped or endorsed in such a manner as to clearly indicate that it has been dispensed by a state liquor store, and all liquors, wines, beverages and alcohol kept, stored or deposited in any place in the city or the police jurisdiction thereof, for the purpose of unlawful sale or disposition, and the vessels and receptacles in which such liquors are contained shall be contraband and subject to seizure and forfeiture. This subsection shall not apply when possession of such beverages is allowed under state law. 
(b)  The municipal judge may declare any alcoholic beverages which have been seized, to be contraband and to declare the same forfeited. The seizure and such declaration by the judge shall constitute such prohibited beverages contraband and upon the entry of an appropriate order of forfeiture the same shall be forfeited. Such beverages shall thereafter be destroyed or may be disposed of in a manner not contrary to the law of the state, as may be directed by the board. 
(c)  If any such beverages shall constitute what is usually termed "wild-cat whiskey," or "stump-juice," the same are further hereby declared to be automatically contraband and shall be forthwith destroyed publicly by the police department of the city; provided however, that no such beverages shall be destroyed or disposed of pending an appeal or right of appeal to any court. 
(d)  Any destruction of any such contraband beverage shall be made publicly by the police department of the city, acting under the direction either of the municipal judge or the board. 
(e)  Any alcoholic beverages found at any point within the city or police jurisdiction thereof, which alcoholic beverages shall have been within the city, or its police jurisdiction for a period of two (2) hours or longer, in possession of any retailer, or for a period of thirty-six (36) hours or longer, in possession of any wholesaler or distributor, not having affixed to the package, the stamps, crowns or lids, as provided by law, are hereby declared to be contraband goods and the same may be seized by the governing body, or any peace officer of the city without a warrant and such goods shall be delivered to the board or its agents; provided further, that any of the goods, wares or merchandise when offered for sale, either at wholesale or retail without the stamps, crowns or lids having been first affixed shall be subject to seizure as hereinabove provided. 
(Code 1964, §§ 3-10, 3-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 28-3-240. 
Sec. 3-18. - Same-Possession, handling, sale, prohibited. 
    The possession, possession for sale, sale, giving away or otherwise dispensing of the liquors, wines, beverages and alcohol as prohibited and defined in section 3-17 is hereby declared to be unlawful. 
(Code 1964, § 3-11) 
Sec. 3-19. - Seizure of vehicles carrying unlawful beverages. 
    Any vehicle not a common carrier, which may be used for the transportation for the purpose of sale of unstamped articles as enumerated in section 3-17 shall be subject to seizure in the manner provided in section 3-17 for goods, wares or merchandise without stamps, crowns or lids; provided further, that should any alcoholic beverages without stamps, crowns or lids as enumerated and defined herein be found in any vehicle which is engaged in the sale, distribution or delivery of taxable alcoholic beverages, the same shall be prima facie evidence that such was there for sale. 
(Code 1964, § 3-13) 
Secs. 3-20-3-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Alcoholic Beverage Licensing Code, Code of Ala., § 28-3A-1. 

Sec. 3-31. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any alcoholic beverages, within the city or its police jurisdiction, for the purpose of sale, or to sell or keep for sale, or offer for sale, without first having procured from the city a license thereof. 
(Ord. No. 107-81, § 10, 4-21-81) 
Sec. 3-32. - Application. 
    The application of any person for any license issued under this article shall be made upon such forms as the finance director or his duly authorized representative, may prescribe. Every private club applicant shall also file with or as a part of its application, a true and correct list of all of its members, officers and directors, a certificate of incorporation or documentation relating to its form of organization, and such other information as the finance director or his duly authorized representative, shall require. All such applications shall be in writing and shall be properly verified by oath of the applicant or its agent. 
(Ord. No. 107-81, § 5, 4-21-81) 
Sec. 3-33. - Compliance with other ordinances as prerequisite. 
    No license under this article shall be issued to any person to sell alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption until the applicant shall comply with the Life Safety Code, the fire prevention code, and the various building codes of the city in effect at the time of such application. 
(Ord. No. 107-81, § 6, 4-21-81) 
Sec. 3-34. - Compliance with zoning ordinance. 
    No license under this article shall be issued to any person unless the alcoholic beverage license requested to be issued has been reviewed by the city and determined that such license will be in compliance with the city's zoning ordinance in effect at the time of the application for the city alcoholic beverage license. 
(Ord. No. 107-81, § 7, 4-21-81; Ord. No. 117-13, 2, 10-15-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 117-13, § 2, adopted October 15, 2013, amended § 3-34 to read as set out herein. Previously § 3-34 was titled zoning restrictions. 
Sec. 3-35. - Minimum requirements for certain establishments. 
    No hotel, motel, lounge, private club or restaurant, retail liquor license shall be issued to any person unless such person's business establishment shall meet the minimum requirements for such establishment as prescribed in their respective definitions in section 3-1. 
(Ord. No. 107-81, § 8, 4-21-81) 
Sec. 3-36. - Persons eligible for licenses. 
    Licenses shall be granted and issued by the city only to reputable individuals who are citizens of the United States or associations whose members are reputable individuals who are citizens of the United States, or to reputable corporations organized under the laws of the state or duly qualified thereunder to do business in Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 107-81, § 9, 4-21-81) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 28-3A-23(b). 
Sec. 3-37. - Fees. 
    Each person licensed by the board, who shall engage in the alcoholic beverage, liquor, beer or wine business within the corporate limits, or the police jurisdiction shall, prior to engaging in such business, pay to the city, for the privilege of so engaging in business, an annual license fee and further license fees as established below: 
(a)  Beer wholesale license. Each person licensed as a beer wholesaler under Section 28-3A-21(a)(4) of the Code of Alabama shall pay to the city an annual license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). Each person licensed as a beer wholesaler having engaged in selling malt or brewed beverages within the police jurisdiction, but outside the corporate limits, shall pay license fees of one-half of the amounts set forth above. 
(b)  Wine wholesaler license. Each person licensed by the board as a wine wholesaler under Section 28-3A-21(a)(4) of the Code of Alabama shall pay to the city an annual license fee of two hundred seventy-five dollars ($275.00). Each person licensed by the board as a wine wholesaler engaged in business outside of the corporate limits, but within the city police jurisdiction, shall pay license fees of one-half of the amount set forth above. 
(c)  Beer and wine wholesaler license. Each person licensed as a beer and wine wholesaler under Section 28-3A-21(a)(4) of the Code of Alabama shall pay to the city an annual license fee of five hundred twenty-five dollars ($525.00). Each person licensed by the board as a beer and wine wholesaler engaged in selling malt or brewed beverages outside the corporate limits, but within the police jurisdiction, shall pay license fees of one-half of the amount set forth above. 
(d)  Lounge retail liquor license. There shall be two (2) classes of lounge retail liquor licenses: 
(1)  Class I. Each person licensed by the board to operate a retail liquor lounge, Class I, under Section 28-3A-21(a)(6) of the Code of Alabama shall pay to the city an annual license fee of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). In addition to said-stated license fee, each such retail liquor lounge licensee shall pay to the city, on or before the fifteenth day of the calendar month succeeding each separate month, for the privilege of so engaging in such business in said calendar month, an additional license tax of three (3) percent of the gross receipts of such business received during such immediate next-preceding month. Each person licensed by the board to operate a retail liquor lounge, Class I, engaging in such business outside of the corporate limits of the city, but within the police jurisdiction, shall pay license fees and license taxes of one-half of the amount set forth above. 
(2)  Class II. Each person licensed by the board to operate a retail liquor lounge, Class II, under Section 28-3A-21(a)(6) of the Code of Alabama shall pay to the city an annual license fee of two thousand two hundred fifty dollars ($2,250.00). In addition to said-stated license fee, each such retail liquor lounge licensee shall pay to the city, on or before the fifteenth day of the calendar month succeeding each calendar month, for the privilege of so engaging in such business in said calendar month, an additional license tax of three (3) percent of the gross receipts of such business received during such immediate next-preceding month. Each person licensed by the board to operate a retail liquor lounge, Class II, engaging in such business outside of the corporate limits of the city, but within the police jurisdiction, shall pay license fees and license taxes of one-half of the amount set forth above. 
(e)  Restaurant retail liquor license. Each person licensed by the board to sell alcoholic beverages in connection with the operation of a restaurant under Section 28-3A-21(a)(7) of the Code of Alabama, shall pay to the city an annual license fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
