Such term does not include a peace officer on strike or a peace officer not on duty. 
(4)  Public building: Any building owned, operated, or maintained by the municipal government of the City of Opelika or any agency or board of the city to which the general public has access for business or other lawful purpose. Such term shall include, but shall not be limited to, city hall, police department, fire stations, public works facilities, sewer treatment plants, water treatment plants, municipal administrative buildings, public libraries, public museums and similar buildings. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on or to have about his or her person upon or within a public building, public park or playground, or the campus of a public school, college or university any firearm, deadly weapon, explosive, or incendiary device. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to law enforcement officers in the performance of their official duties. Moreover, this section shall not apply to private security personnel who possess firearms within the city or police jurisdiction; provided, that such private security personnel are actually engaged in providing security to a public building, public park, playground or public school campus pursuant to a valid contract with the municipal government, or any agency or board of such municipality. 
(d)  It is no defense under this section that such person holds or possesses a valid firearm license or permit. It is the intent of this section to control the accessibility of firearms and deadly weapons in public buildings and other public places. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit fireworks displays and firearms exhibitions, provided such displays and exhibitions are approved by the city council in advance of the date of display or exhibition. Moreover, nothing in this section shall prohibit the use of firearms, deadly weapons, and blank cartridges for a show or theater or ceremonial purposes in athletic or sports or for use by military organizations. 
(f)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to handguns. The subject matter of handguns is reserved to the state legislature pursuant to Section 11-45-1.1, Code of Alabama. Any person who carries a pistol on to a public building, public park or playground, or the campus of a public school, college or university shall be subject to arrest and prosecution pursuant to the provisions of Section 13A-11-52, Code of Alabama. 
(g)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. The general penalties in effect in the city and prescribed in section 1-8 of this Code are hereby adopted as the penalty provisions for violations of this section. 
(Ord. No. 125-93, § 1, 11-2-93) 
Secs. 19-498-19-506. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - GAMBLING 

Sec. 19-507. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions apply to this article: 
    Advance gambling activity: A person "advances gambling activity" if he engages in conduct that materially aids any form of gambling activity. Conduct of this nature includes but is not limited to conduct directed toward the creation or establishment of the particular game, contest, scheme, device or activity involved, toward the acquisition or maintenance of premises, paraphernalia, equipment or apparatus therefor, toward the solicitation or inducement of persons to participate therein, toward the actual conduct of the playing phases thereof, toward the arrangement of any of its financial or recording phases or toward any other phase of its operation. A person advances gambling activity if, having substantial proprietary control or other authoritative control over premises being used with his knowledge for purposes of gambling activity, he permits that activity to occur or continue or makes no effort to prevent its occurrence or continuation. 
    Bookmaking: Advancing gambling activity by unlawfully accepting bets from members of the public as a business, rather than in a casual or personal fashion, upon the outcome of future contingent events. 
    Contest of chance: Any contest, game, gaming scheme or gaming device in which the outcome depends in a material degree upon an element of chance, notwithstanding that skill of the contestants may also be a factor therein. 
    Gambling: A person engages in gambling if he stakes or risks something of value upon the outcome of a contest of chance or a future contingent event not under his control or influence, upon an agreement or understanding that he or someone else will receive something of value in the event of a certain outcome. Gambling does not include bona fide business transactions valid under the law of contracts, including but not limited to contracts for the purchase or sale at a future date of securities or commodities, and agreements to compensate for loss caused by the happening of chance, including but not limited to contracts of indemnity or guaranty and life, health or accident insurance. 
    Gambling device: Any device, machine, paraphernalia or equipment that is normally used or usable in the playing phases of any gambling activity, whether that activity consists of gambling between persons or gambling by a person involving the playing of a machine. However, lottery tickets, policy slips and other items used in the playing phases of lottery and policy schemes are not gambling devices within this definition. 
    Lottery or policy: Any unlawful gambling scheme in which: 
a.  The players pay or agree to pay something of value for chances, represented and differentiated by numbers or by combinations of numbers or by some other medium, one or more of which chances are to be designated by the winning ones; and 
b.  The winning chances are to be determined by a drawing or by some other fortuitous method; and 
c.  The holders of the winning chances are to receive something of value. 
    Pari-mutuel, mutuel or the numbers game: A form of lottery in which the winning chances or plays are not determined upon the basis of a drawing or other act on the part of persons conducting or connected with the scheme, but upon the basis of the outcome of a future contingent event or events otherwise unrelated to the particular scheme. 
    Player: A person who engages in any form of gambling solely as a contestant or bettor, without receiving or becoming entitled to receive any profit therefrom other than personal gambling winnings, and without otherwise rendering any material assistance to the establishment, conduct or operation of the particular gambling activity. 
    Profit from gambling activity: A person "profits from gambling activity" if he accepts or receives money or other property pursuant to an agreement or understanding with any person whereby he shares or is to share in the proceeds of gambling activity. 
    Slot machine: A gambling device that, as a result of the insertion of a coin or other object, operates, either completely automatically or with the aid of some physical act by the player, in such a manner that, depending upon elements of chance, it may eject something of value. A device so constructed or readily adaptable or convertible to such use is no less a slot machine because it is not in working order or because some mechanical act of manipulation or repair is required to accomplish its adaptation, conversion or workability. Nor is it any less a slot machine because apart from its use or adaptability as such it may also sell or deliver something of value on a basis other than chance. 
    Something of value: Any money or property, any token, object or article exchangeable for money or property or any form of credit or promise directly or indirectly contemplating transfer of money or property or of any interest therein, or involving extension of a service entertainment or a privilege of playing at a game or scheme without charge. 
    Unlawful: Not specifically authorized by law. 
(Code 1964, §§ 17-55-17-66) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-20. 
Sec. 19-508. - Simple gambling. 
(a)  A person commits the crime of simple gambling if he knowingly advances or profits from unlawful gambling activity as a player. 
(b)  It is a defense to a prosecution under this section that a person charged with being a player was engaged in a social game in a private place. The burden of injecting the issue is on the defendant, but this does not shift the burden of proof. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-21. 
Sec. 19-509. - Promoting gambling. 
(a)  A person commits the crime of promoting gambling if he knowingly advances or profits from unlawful gambling activity otherwise than as a player. 
(b)  It is no defense relating to a lottery that the lottery itself is drawn or conducted outside Alabama and is not in violation of the laws of the jurisdiction in which it is drawn or conducted. 
(Code 1964, §§ 17-55-17-66) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., §§ 13A-12-22, 13A-12-29. 
Sec. 19-510. - Conspiracy to promote gambling. 
(a)  A person commits the crime of conspiracy to promote gambling if he conspires to advance or profit from gambling activity otherwise than as a player. 
(b)  "Conspire" means to engage in activity constituting a criminal conspiracy as defined in section 13-98 of this Code. 
(Code 1964, §§ 17-55-17-66) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-23. 
Sec. 19-511. - Possession of gambling records in the first degree. 
    A person commits the crime of possession of gambling records in the first degree if with knowledge of the contents thereof, he possesses any writing, paper, instrument or article: 
(1)  Of a kind commonly used in the operation or promotion of a bookmaking scheme or enterprise, and constituting, reflecting or representing more than five (5) bets, or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00); 
(2)  Of a kind commonly used in the operation, promotion or playing of a lottery or mutuel scheme or enterprise, and constituting, reflecting or representing more than five (5) plays or chances therein. 
(Code 1964, §§ 17-55-17-66) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-24. 
Sec. 19-512. - Possession of gambling records in the second degree. 
    A person commits the crime of possession of gambling records in the second degree if with knowledge of the contents thereof, he possesses any writing, paper, instrument or article: 
(1)  Of a kind commonly and peculiarly used in the operation or promotion of a bookmaking scheme or enterprise; or 
(2)  Of a kind commonly and peculiarly used in the operation, promotion or playing of a lottery or mutuel scheme or enterprise. 
(Code 1964, §§ 17-55-17-66) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-25. 
Sec. 19-513. - Defense to prosecution for possession of gambling records. 
    A person does not commit the crime of possession of gambling records in either degree if the writing, paper, instrument or article possessed by the defendant is neither used nor intended to be used in the operation or promotion of a bookmaking scheme or enterprise, or in the operation, promotion or playing of a lottery or mutuel scheme or enterprise. The burden of injecting the issue is on the defendant, but this does not shift the burden of proof. 
(Code 1964, §§ 17-55-17-66) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-26. 
Sec. 19-514. - Possession of gambling device. 
    A person commits the crime of possession of a gambling device if with knowledge of the character thereof he manufactures, sells, transports, places or possesses, or conducts or negotiates any transaction affecting or designed to affect ownership, custody or use of: 
(1)  A slot machine; or 
(2)  Any other gambling device, with the intention that it be used in the advancement of unlawful gambling activity. 
(Code 1964, §§ 17-55-17-66) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-27. 
Sec. 19-515. - Prima facie evidence. 
(a)  Proof of possession of any gambling device or any gambling record specified in sections 19-511 and 19-512 of this Code is prima facie evidence of possession thereof with knowledge of its character or contents. 
(b)  In any prosecution under this article in which it is necessary to prove the occurrence of a sporting event: 
(1)  A published report of its occurrence in any daily newspaper, magazine or other periodically printed publication of general circulation, or 
(2)  Evidence that a description of some aspect of the event was written, printed or otherwise noted at the place in which a violation of this chapter is alleged to have been committed, 
shall be admissible in evidence and shall constitute prima facie proof of the occurrence of the event. 
(Code 1964, §§ 17-55-17-66) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-28. 
Sec. 19-516. - Forfeiture of gambling devices and gambling proceeds. 
(a)  Any gambling device or gambling record possessed or used in violation of this article is forfeited to the city, and shall by court order be destroyed or otherwise disposed of as the court directs. 
(b)  Any vehicle possessed or used in violation of this article may be forfeited to the city. 
(c)  Money used as bets or takes in gambling activity in violation of this article is forfeited to the city and by court order shall be transmitted to the general fund. 
(Code 1964, §§ 17-55-17-66) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-30. 
Sec. 19-517. - Possession of wagering tax stamp. 
(a)  The holding, owning, having in possession of, or paying the tax of a wagering occupational tax stamp issued by the internal revenue authorities of the United States shall be prima facie evidence against the person holding such stamp in any prosecution of such person for a violation of this article. 
(b)  Upon the trial of such person, proof of the owning, holding or possession of such stamp may be made by two (2) witnesses who have seen such stamp in the place of business of the holder or on his person, or by the production of the original stamp with proof by one or more witnesses that it is the property of the defendant, or by production by the state of a copy of such stamp certified by the director of the issuing federal internal revenue district as being a copy of the stamp originally issued to the defendant. Proof made as herein provided shall be sufficient evidence, without explanation, to convict of a violation of this article. 
(Code 1964, §§ 17-55-17-66) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., §§ 13A-12-90, 13A-12-92. 
Secs. 19-518-19-530. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - OBSCENITY AND RELATED OFFENSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 19-531. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division, the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
(1)  Obscene: Such term means that: 
a.  To the average person, applying contemporary community standards, the work or performance, taken as a whole, appeals to the prurient interest; and 
b.  The work or performance depicts or describes, in a patently offensive way, sexual conduct, actual or simulated, normal or perverted; and 
c.  The work or performance, taken as a whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
(2)  Work: Any book, magazine, newspaper or other printed or written material, or any picture, drawing, photograph, film, videotape, motion picture or other pictorial representation, or any sound recording, or any statue or other figure, or any other article, device or material. 
(3)  Performance: Any film, videotape, motion picture, sound recording, play, dance or other exhibition or presentation, whether pictured, animated or live, presented or performed before any audience of one or more persons. 
(4)  Sexual conduct: Such term means: 
a.  Any act of masturbation, urination, defecation, sado-masochistic abuse, sexual intercourse or any other physical contact with a person's unclothed genitals, pubic area, buttocks or the breast or breasts of a female, whether alone or between members of the same or opposite sex or between a human and an animal, in an apparent act of sexual stimulation, gratification or perversion; or 
b.  Lewd exhibition of the genitals. 
(5)  Sexual intercourse: Intercourse, whether genital-genital, oral-genital, anal-genital or oral-anal, and whether between persons of the same or opposite sex or between a human and an animal. 
(6)  Sado-masochistic abuse: Flagellation or torture, in an apparent act of sexual stimulation, by or upon a person who is nude or clad in undergarments or in a revealing or bizarre costume, or the binding or physically restraining of a person who is so clothed, for the apparent purpose of sexual stimulation. 
(7)  Knowingly: The intentional doing of an act involving a work or performance when a person knows the nature of the work or performance. A person knows the nature of the work or performance when he has knowledge of, or good reason to know, or a reasonable ground for belief which warrants further inspection or inquiry of, the character and content of the work or performance. 
(8)  Display publicly: To expose, place, exhibit or in any fashion display, in any location, public or private, any work in such a manner that the work can either be readily seen and its content or character distinguished by normal unaided vision or be physically examined, by viewing it or examining it from any place to which members of the general public are invited. 
(9)  Distribute: To transfer possession of or title to for any monetary consideration. 
(10)  Owner: Any person who owns or has legal right to possession of any work. 
(Code 1964, § 17-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-150. 
Sec. 19-532. - Prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly: 
(1)  To send or cause to be sent, or bring or cause to be brought, into this city for sale or distribution, any obscene work; or 
(2)  Within this city, to display publicly, sell or distribute any obscene work, or to possess any obscene work with intent to exhibit it for monetary consideration, or to make, manufacture, print, prepare, publish, produce or possess any obscene work with intent to sell or distribute it. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly, for any monetary consideration, to exhibit by any method or means any obscene performance, or knowingly, for any monetary consideration, to aid or abet in the exhibition of any obscene performance. 
(c)  This section shall not apply where a person is acting in furtherance of a bona fide scientific or educational purpose. The provisions of this section shall not apply to broadcasts or telecasts through facilities licensed under the Federal Communications Act. 
(Code 1964, § 17-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., §§ 13A-12-151-13A-12-153, 13A-12-159. 
Sec. 19-533. - Search warrants; seizure of allegedly obscene works; return of seized works. 
    Search warrants for the seizure of any allegedly obscene work as evidence in any prosecution for violation of any of the provisions of this division shall be issued as provided by law, except as such law is inconsistent with the provisions of this division. The issuing judge or magistrate may, at his own discretion, view the said work at the scene of its exhibit, if the said work is then being publicly exhibited within the state. The city shall reimburse the issuing judge or magistrate for the price of admission and for the cost of transportation paid by him in any such case. If the issuing judge or magistrate finds probable cause, then he shall issue a search warrant for the seizure of the said work; provided, that the quantity of any allegedly obscene work seized shall be no greater than is reasonably necessary for the purpose of obtaining evidence for criminal prosecution. If no criminal prosecution is begun with respect to any allegedly obscene work seized within twenty-four (24) hours of its seizure, then the work must be returned to the person or premises from which it was seized. 
(Code 1964, § 17-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-155. 
Sec. 19-534. - Hearing for preliminary determination of obscenity. 
    At any time after seizure, and prior to trial, the city, defendant or owner may file with the district court a written demand for an adversary hearing for the purpose of obtaining a preliminary determination of obscenity. Said hearing shall be held within time limits mandated by the United States Constitution and the Alabama Constitution. The sole question to be determined at the hearing shall be whether or not the work seized is obscene. The burden of proof shall be upon the city and shall be the same as the burden of proof in civil cases. The court shall render its decision within one day after the conclusion of the hearing. If the court does not find the work to be obscene, it shall immediately order the work to be returned. Should the court find the work to be obscene, it shall order the work to be retained as evidence in the criminal prosecution. A finding by the court that the work is obscene shall not be admissible at trial in the criminal prosecution. The defendant or owner may petition the court at any time prior to a judicial determination in an adversary proceeding for permission to copy the work at his own expense. Upon a showing that other copies of the work are not available, the court shall issue an order permitting the petitioner, under such conditions as the court deems necessary, to copy the work pending any judicial determination of obscenity in an adversary hearing. Such an order shall not be deemed to grant immunity to petitioner for any future criminal violations. 
(Code 1964, § 17-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-156. 
Sec. 19-535. - Forfeiture and destruction of works. 
    Any obscene work used in any violation of this division is subject to forfeiture. The district attorney in the county where the work is seized may file a complaint in the circuit court praying that such seized work be declared contraband, be forfeited to the state and be destroyed. The work and the owner of the work, if known, shall be made a party defendant to the complaint. It shall be a defense to the action that the owner was not a consenting party or privy to the violation. 
(Code 1964, § 17-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-158. 
Secs. 19-536-19-545. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MATERIAL HARMFUL TO MINORS 

Sec. 19-546. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division, the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
(1)  Minor: Any unmarried person under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(2)  Obscene: Such term means that: 
a.  To the average person, applying contemporary community standards, the work or performance, taken as a whole, appeals to the prurient interest of minors; and 
b.  The work or performance depicts or describes, in a patently offensive way for minors, sexual conduct, actual or simulated, normal or perverted; and 
c.  The work or performance, taken as a whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value for minors. 
(3)  Work: Any book, magazine, newspaper or other printed or written material, or any picture, drawing, photograph, film, videotape, motion picture or other pictorial representation, or any sound recording, or any statute or other figure, or any other article, device or material. 
(4)  Performance: Any film, videotape, motion picture, sound recording, play, dance or other exhibition or presentation, whether pictured, animated or live, presented or performed before any audience of one or more persons. 
(5)  Sexual conduct: Such term means: 
a.  Any act of masturbation, urination, defecation, sado-masochistic abuse, sexual intercourse or any other physical contact with a person's unclothed genitals, pubic area, buttocks or the breast or breasts of a female, whether alone or between members of the same or opposite sex or between a human and an animal, in an apparent act of sexual stimulation, gratification or perversion; or 
b.  Lewd exhibition of the genitals; or 
c.  Nudity. 
(6)  Sexual intercourse: Intercourse, whether genital-genital, oral-genital, anal-genital or oral-anal, and whether between persons of the same or opposite sex or between a human and an animal. 
(7)  Sado-masochistic abuse: Flagellation or torture, in an apparent act of sexual stimulation, by or upon a person who is nude or clad in undergarments or in a revealing or bizarre costume, or the binding or physically restraining of a person who is so clothed, for the apparent purpose of sexual stimulation. 
(8)  Nudity: The showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering, or the showing of the female breasts with less than a fully opaque covering of any portion thereof below the top of the nipple, or the depiction of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state. 
(9)  Knowingly: The intentional doing of an act involving a work or performance when a person knows the nature of the work or performance. A person knows the nature of the work or performance when he has knowledge of, or good reason to know, or a reasonable ground for belief which warrants further inspection or inquiry of the character and content of the work or performance. 
(10)  Distribute: To transfer possession of or title to, whether with or without monetary consideration. 
(11)  Owner: Any person who owns or has legal right to possession of any work. 
(12)  Display for sale: To expose, place, exhibit or in any fashion display any work for the purpose of the sale of such work to any person in such a manner that the work can be physically examined or seen. 
(Code 1964, § 17-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-170. 
Sec. 19-547. - Prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to show, exhibit, display, sell or distribute to a minor any obscene work, or knowingly to possess any obscene work with the intent to show, exhibit, display, sell or distribute it to a minor, or knowingly to display for sale, in any business establishment frequented by minors or where minors are or may be invited as part of the general public, any obscene work or any portion whatsoever of any obscene work. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly by any method or means to exhibit, or aid or abet in the exhibition of, any obscene performance with knowledge that a minor is present in the audience, or knowingly by any method or means to exhibit, or aid or abet in the exhibition of, any obscene performance with reckless disregard as to whether a minor is present in an audience, or knowingly by any method or means to exhibit, or aid or abet in the exhibition of, any obscene performance where it is likely or probable that a minor is present in an audience. 
(c)  This section shall not apply: 
(1)  Where a person is acting in furtherance of a bona fide scientific or educational purpose; or 
(2)  Where a person is the parent or guardian of the minor; or 
(3)  Where the minor is accompanied by his parent or guardian and the parent or guardian waives the application of this section with respect to the particular transaction. 
(d)  An honest mistake as to the age of the minor shall constitute a defense to prosecution under this division, but only if the person charged made a reasonable, bona fide attempt to ascertain the true age of such minor. 
(Code 1964, § 17-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., §§ 13A-12-171-13A-12-175. 
Sec. 19-548. - Search warrants; seizure of allegedly obscene works; return of seized works. 
    Search warrants for the seizure of any allegedly obscene work as evidence in any prosecution for violation of any of the provisions of this division shall be issued as provided by law, except as such law is inconsistent with the provisions of this division. The issuing judge or magistrate may, at his own discretion, view the said work at the scene of its exhibit if the said work is then being publicly exhibited within the city. The city shall reimburse the issuing judge or magistrate for the price of admission and for the cost of transportation paid by him in any such case. If the issuing judge or magistrate finds probable cause, then he shall issue a search warrant for the seizure of the said work; provided, that the quantity of any allegedly obscene work seized shall be no greater than is reasonably necessary for the purpose of obtaining evidence for criminal prosecution. If no criminal prosecution is begun with respect to any allegedly obscene work seized within twenty-four (24) hours of its seizure, then the work must be returned to the person or premises from which it was seized. 
(Code 1964, § 17-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-176. 
Sec. 19-549. - Hearing for preliminary determination of obscenity. 
    At any time after seizure, and prior to trial, the state, defendant or owner may file with the district court a written demand for an adversary hearing for the purpose of obtaining a preliminary determination of obscenity. Said hearing shall be held within time limits mandated by the United States Constitution and the Alabama Constitution. The sole question to be determined at the hearing shall be whether or not the work seized is obscene. The burden of proof shall be upon the state and shall be the same as the burden of proof in civil cases. The court shall render its decision within one day after the conclusion of the hearing. If the court does not find the work to be obscene, it shall immediately order the work to be returned. Should the court find the work to be obscene, it shall order the work to be retained as evidence in the criminal prosecution. A finding by the court that the work is obscene shall not be admissible at trial in the criminal prosecution. The defendant or owner may petition the court at any time prior to a judicial determination in an adversary proceeding for permission to copy the work at his own expense. Upon a showing that other copies of the work are not available the court shall issue an order permitting the petitioner, under such conditions as the court deems necessary, to copy the work pending any judicial determination of obscenity in an adversary hearing. Such an order shall not be deemed to grant immunity to petitioner for any future criminal violations. 
(Code 1964, § 17-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-177. 
Sec. 19-550. - Forfeiture and destruction of works. 
    Any obscene work used in any violation of this division is subject to forfeiture. The city attorney may file a complaint in the circuit court praying that such seized work be declared contraband, be forfeited to the state and be destroyed. The work and the owner of the work, if known, shall be made a party defendant to the complaint. It shall be a defense to the action that the owner was not a consenting party or privy to the violation of this division. 
(Code 1964, § 17-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-179. 
DIVISION 3. - NUDITY AND SEXUAL CONDUCT IN ESTABLISHMENTS DEALING IN ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3. 

Sec. 19-551. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this division, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context otherwise requires: 
    Establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages: Any business establishment operating within the city limits or police jurisdiction of Opelika, Alabama which sells, dispenses or otherwise allows the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
    Person: Any individual, firm, association, joint venture, partnership, estate, trust, business trust, syndicate, fiduciary, corporation, or any combination thereof, or any other entity. Whenever used herein, the words "association" and "partnership" shall mean the partners or members thereof and as applied to "corporation" shall mean the officers thereof, except as to incorporated clubs the term "person" shall mean such individual or individuals who under the bylaws of such clubs, shall have jurisdiction over the possession and sale of liquor therein. 
(Ord. No. 123-91, § 2, 9-3-91) 
Sec. 19-552. - Nudity, sexual conduct prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall expose to public view his or her genitals, pubic area, vulva, anus, anal cleft or cleavage, or any simulation thereof in an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  No female person shall expose to public view any portion of her breasts below the top of the areola or any simulation thereof in an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(c)  No person maintaining, owning or operating an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages shall suffer or permit any person to expose to public view his or her genitals, pubic area, vulva, anus, anal cleft or cleavage or simulation thereof within the establishment dealing with alcoholic beverages. 
(d)  No person maintaining, owning or operating an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages shall suffer or permit any female person to expose to public view any portion of her breasts below the top of the areola or any simulation thereof within the establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(e)  No person shall engage in, and no person maintaining, owning or operating an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages shall suffer or permit, any sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, any sexual act which is prohibited by law, touching, caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus, or genitals or the simulation thereof within an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(f)  No person shall cause and no person maintaining, owning or operating an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages shall suffer or permit the exposition of any graphic representation, including pictures or the projection of film, which depicts human genitals, pubic area, vulva, anus, anal cleft or cleavage, female breasts below the top of the areola, sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, any sexual act prohibited by law, touching, caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus, or genitals, or any simulation thereof within any establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(g)  The above subsections (a)-(f) shall not apply to any legitimate, mainstream movie theater that shows G, PG, PG-13, or R rated movies, as designated by the Motion Picture Association of America. As used in this subsection, "movie theater" means a motion picture theater that is being utilized solely for exhibition of motion pictures. No films, still pictures, electronic reproductions or other visual reproductions which are in violation of the state anti-obscenity enforcement act codified at Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 13A-12-200.1 to 13A-12-200.12, or are in violation of federal law regarding pornography, indecency or obscenity shall be shown or displayed in any movie theater that is allowed to sell alcoholic beverages for on premises consumption pursuant to a valid license. 
(Ord. No. 123-91, § 2, 9-3-91; Ord. No. 114-14, § 1, 5-20-14) 
Sec. 19-553. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this division upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and by imprisonment in the city jail for not more than six (6) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment and also costs of court for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 123-91, § 2, 9-3-91) 
Secs. 19-554-19-565. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - OTHER OFFENSES 

Sec. 19-566. - Creating a hazard. 
    A person commits the crime of creating a hazard if: 
(1)  Having discarded, in any place accessible to children, a container having a compartment of more than one and one-half (11/2) cubic feet capacity and a door or lid that locks or fastens automatically when closed and cannot easily be opened from the inside, he fails to remove the door, lid or locking or fastening device; or 
(2)  Being the owner or otherwise having possession of land upon which there is an abandoned well, cistern or cesspool of a depth of four (4) feet or more and a top width of twelve (12) inches or more, he fails to fill, cover or fence it with a suitable protective construction. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-11-220. 
Sec. 19-567. - Unlawfully refusing to yield party line. 
(a)  A person commits the crime of refusing to yield a party line if he intentionally refuses immediately to yield a party line after he is informed that it is needed for an emergency call. 
(b)  The term "party line" means a subscriber's line telephone circuit consisting of two (2) or more main telephone stations connected therewith, each having a distinctive ring or telephone number. 
(c)  The term "emergency call" means a telephone call to a police or fire department, or for medical aid or ambulance service, necessitated by a situation in which human life or property is in jeopardy and prompt summoning of aid is essential. 
(d)  It shall be a defense to a prosecution under this section that at the time of the request the line was being used for another emergency call. The burden of injecting this defense shall be upon the defendant, but this does not shift the burden of proof. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-11-222. 
Sec. 19-568. - Falsely requesting use of party line for emergency. 
(a)  A person commits the crime of falsely requesting use of party line for emergency if he states that a party line is needed for an emergency call knowing such statement to be false. 
(b)  The term "party line," as defined in section 19-567 of this Code, is incorporated in this section. 
(c)  The term "emergency call," as defined in section 19-567 of this Code, is incorporated in this section. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-11-223. 
Sec. 19-569. - Certain acts prohibited on Sunday. 
(a)  Any person who compels his child, apprentice or servant to perform any labor on Sunday, except the customary domestic duties of daily necessity or comfort, or works of charity or who engages in shooting, hunting, gaming, card playing or racing on that day, or who, being a merchant or shopkeeper, druggist excepted, keeps open store on Sunday, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the operation of railroads, airlines, bus lines, communications, public utilities or steamboats or other vessels navigating the waters of this state, or to any manufacturing establishment which is required to be kept in constant operation, or to the sale of gasoline or other motor fuels or motor oils, nor shall this section prohibit the sale of newspapers, or the operation of newsstands, or automobile repair shops, florist shops, fruit stands, ice cream shops or parlors, lunch stands or restaurants, delicatessens or plants engaged in the manufacture or sale of ice; provided, that such business establishments are not operated in conjunction with some other kind or type of business which is prohibited by this section. It shall also be lawful to engage in motorcycle and automobile racing on Sunday, whether admission is charged or not. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-1. 
Sec. 19-570. - Holding public markets on Sunday. 
    Any person who opens, or causes to be opened, for the purpose of selling or trading, any public market or place on Sunday, or opens, or causes to be opened, any stall or shop therein, or connected therewith, or brings anything for sale or barter to such market or place, or offers the same for sale therein on that day, or buys or sells therein on that day, including livestock or cattle, shall, on conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor, Any place where people assemble for the purchase and sale of goods, wares and merchandise, provisions, cattle or other articles is a market house or place within the meaning of this section. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-2. 
Sec. 19-571. - Selling cigarettes to minors. 
    Any person who sells, barters, exchanges or gives to any minor any cigarettes, cigarette tobacco or cigarette paper, or any substitute for either of them shall, on conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-3. 
Sec. 19-572. - Keeping cockpit; cockfighting. 
    Any person who keeps a cockpit or who in any public place fights cocks shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-4. 
Sec. 19-573. - Promoting prostitution in the third degree. 
(a)  A person commits the crime of promoting prostitution in the third degree if he knowingly advances or profits from prostitution. 
(b)  A person "advances prostitution" if, acting other than as a prostitute or a patron of a prostitute, he knowingly causes or aids a person to commit or engage in prostitution, procures or solicits patrons for prostitution, provides persons or premises for prostitution purposes, operates or assists in the operation of a house of prostitution or a prostitution enterprise. 
(c)  A person "profits from prostitution" if, acting other than as a prostitute receiving compensation for personally-rendered prostitution services, he accepts or receives money or other property pursuant to a prior agreement with any person whereby he participates or is to participate in the proceeds of prostitution activity. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., §§ 13A-12-110, 13A-12-113. 
Sec. 19-574. - Public lewdness. 
    A person commits the crime of public lewdness if: 
(1)  He exposes his anus or genitals in a public place and is reckless about whether another may be present who will be offended or alarmed by his act; or 
(2)  He does any lewd act in a public place which he knows is likely to be observed by others who would be affronted or alarmed. 
(Code 1964, § 17-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-12-130. 
Sec. 19-575. - Adultery. 
(a)  A person commits adultery when he engages in sexual intercourse with another person who is not his spouse and lives in cohabitation with that other person when he or that other person is married. 
(b)  A person does not commit a crime under this section if he reasonably believes that he and the other person are unmarried persons. The burden of injecting this issue is on the defendant, but this does not change the burden of proof. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-13-2. 
Sec. 19-576. - Nonsupport. 
(a)  A man or woman commits the crime of nonsupport if he or she intentionally fails to provide support which that person is able to provide and which that person knows he or she is legally obligated to provide to a dependent spouse or child less than nineteen (19) years of age. 
(b)  "Support" includes but is not limited to food, shelter, clothing, medical attention and other necessary care, as determined elsewhere by law. 
(c)  "Child" includes a child born out of wedlock whose paternity has been admitted by the actor or has been established in a civil suit. 
(Code 1964, § 17-27) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-13-4. 
Sec. 19-577. - Abandonment of child. 
    A man or woman commits the crime of abandonment of a child when, being a parent, guardian or other person legally charged with the care or custody of a child less than eighteen (18) years old, he or she deserts such child in any place with intent wholly to abandon it. 
(Code 1964, § 17-27) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-13-5. 
Sec. 19-578. - Endangering welfare of child. 
(a)  A man or woman commits the crime of endangering the welfare of a child when: 
(1)  He or she knowingly directs or authorizes a child less than sixteen (16) years of age to engage in an occupation involving a substantial risk of danger to his life or health; or 
(2)  He or she, as a parent, guardian or other person legally charged with the care or custody of a child less than eighteen (18) years of age, fails to exercise reasonable diligence in the control of such child to prevent him or her from becoming a "dependent child" or a "delinquent child," as defined in section 12-15-1 of the Code of Alabama. 
(b)  A person does not commit an offense under section 19-576 of this Code or this section for the sole reason he provides a child under the age of nineteen (19) years or a dependent spouse with remedial treatment by spiritual means alone in accordance with the tenets and practices of a recognized church or religious denomination by a duly accredited practitioner thereof in lieu of medical treatment. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-13-6. 
Sec. 19-579. - Marathon, etc., contests prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to promote, advertise or conduct any marathon dance contests, walkathon contests or similar endurance contests, by whatever name called, of walking, dancing, riding or running, and it shall be unlawful for any person to participate in any marathon dance contest, walkathon contest or similar physical endurance contest by walking, dancing, riding or running continuing or intended to continue for a period of more than eight (8) consecutive hours, whether or not an admission is charged or a prize awarded, and it shall be unlawful for any person to participate in more than one (1) such contest or performance within any period of forty-eight (48) hours. 
(b)  Each and every day that any person shall continue such a contest or engage in any such activities or each day's participation in such contest or advertisement of the same or each day any act is done in violation of the provisions of this section shall be and constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 13A-14-3. 
Sec. 19-580. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section I of Ord. No. 118-00, adopted June 6, 2000, repealed § 19-580 which pertained to entry upon private premises of itinerant, transient vendors, etc., and derived from § 17-11 of the 1964 Code. 
Sec. 19-581. - Posting, tacking, painting bills and signs. 
    No person shall paint, print, post or in any way affix any picture, bill, banner or advertising matter of any kind upon any post, hydrant, curb, sidewalk or other public improvement in any public ground or street nor upon any bridge or part of the same or public building, structure or erection of any kind belonging to the city, nor cause the same to be done, unless express consent therefor shall have been first granted by the governing body of the city, nor upon any mast or pole in any street or alley, erected or used for supporting or conducting any wire or cable or incidental thereto, or upon any tree, lamp post or any structure or erection of any kind within the limits of any public street or ground in the city whether the permission therefor has been granted by the owner or otherwise. 
(Code 1964, § 17-2) 
Sec. 19-582. - Placing handbills in vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place any dodger, handbill, picture or advertisement of any kind or nature in any automobile or other motor vehicle within the corporate limits of the city or its police jurisdiction without the permission of the owner or operator of such vehicle. 
(Code 1964, § 17-1) 
Sec. 19-583. - Telephone soliciting. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, society or association, including but not limited to religious, fraternal, patriotic or charitable organizations, to use the telephone as a means of soliciting another to make a donation or to subscribe to or for advertising, or to use the telephone as a means of soliciting another to give or pay money or anything of value for or in return for any ticket, flag, tag, badge, flower, token or symbol, or to use the telephone as a means of arranging an engagement for such solicitation for any purpose unless a permit to do so has first been obtained from the governing body of the city, except however, as provided in subsection (b). 
(b)  This section shall not apply to such solicitation of advertisements by or for any outdoor advertising agency, or to such solicitation by or for any daily or weekly newspaper which is regularly published or delivered in the city or county or to such solicitation by or for any radio or television station which broadcasts regular programs in the city or county, or to such solicitation of donations by or for any society or organization provided such solicitation is of the members of such society or organization only. 
(Code 1964, § 17-22) 
Sec. 19-584. - Possession of marijuana. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any marijuana for his personal use only in the city limits or the police jurisdiction thereof. 
(b)  The term "marijuana" means any part of the plant Cannabis sativa l., whether growing or not; the seeds thereof; the resin extracted from any part of the plant; in every compound, manufactured salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of the plant, its seeds or resin. It does not include the mature stalks of the plant; fiber produced from the stalks; or cake made from the seeds of the plant; any of the compound, manufactured salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of the mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, or cake; or the sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of germination. 
(Code 1964, § 17-18.1) 
Sec. 19-585. - Fireworks-Definitions. 
    Wherever used herein, the word "fireworks" shall mean and include any combustible or explosive composition, or any substances or combination of substances, or device prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or an audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include blank cartridges, toy pistols, toy cannons, toy canes, or toy guns in which explosives are used, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, roman candles, daygo bombs, sparklers or other devices of like construction and any device containing any explosive or flammable compound, or any tablet or other device containing any explosive substances, except that the term "fireworks" shall not include any auto-flares, paper caps containing not in excess of an average of twenty-five one-hundredths (0.25) of a grain of explosive content per cap and toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns or other devices for use of such caps, the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times. 
(Ord. No. 109-87, § 1, 4-7-87) 
Sec. 19-586. - Same-Manufacture, sale and discharge. 
(a)  The manufacture of fireworks within the city or its police jurisdiction is prohibited except under special permits as are required by local and state regulations. 
(b)  Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for any person to possess, store, to offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at retail, or use or explode any fireworks within the corporate limits; provided, that the city council may grant permits for fireworks displays to organizations of a civic nature, upon recommendation of the chief of the fire department, provided such displays are supervised and controlled by the fire department. Every such use and display shall be handled by a competent operator approved by the fire chief of the City of Opelika and shall be of such character and so located, discharged or fired as not to be hazardous to property or endanger persons. The city shall not regulate the sale, possession or use of fireworks within the police jurisdiction of the city but beyond the corporate limits. 
(c)  Applications for fireworks displays within the corporate limits shall be in writing at least ten (10) days in advance of the date of display. After such privilege shall be granted, sale, possession, use and distribution of fireworks for such display shall be lawful for that purpose only. No permit granted hereunder shall be transferable. Further, no permit for a fireworks display shall be required for the use, possession, or sale of fireworks within the police jurisdiction but beyond corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. 109-87, § 2, 4-7-87; Ord. No. 125-90, § 1) 
Sec. 19-587. - Same-Bond for display required. 
    The permittee shall furnish a bond or certificate of insurance in an amount deemed adequate by the chief of the fire department for the payment of all damages which may be caused to a person or persons or to property by reason of the permitted display, and arising from any acts of the permittee, his agents, employees or subcontractors. 
(Ord. No. 109-87, § 3, 4-7-87) 
Sec. 19-588. - Same-Disposal of unfired fireworks. 
    Any fireworks that remain unfired after the display is conducted shall be immediately disposed of in a way safe for the particular type of fireworks remaining. 
(Ord. No. 109-87, § 4, 4-7-87) 
Sec. 19-589. - Same-Seizure. 
    The chief of the fire department shall seize, take, remove or cause to be removed at the expense of the owner all stocks of fireworks offered or exposed for sale, stored, or held in violation of the ordinance from which sections 19-585 through 19-590 were derived. 
(Ord. No. 109-87, § 5, 4-7-87) 
Sec. 19-590. - Same-Authorized use. 
    Nothing in the ordinance from which sections 19-585 through 19-589 and this section were derived shall be construed to prohibit the use of fireworks by railroads or other transportation agencies for signal purposes of illumination, or the sale or use of blank cartridges for a show or theater, or for signal or ceremonial purposes in athletic or sports or for use by military organizations. 
(Ord. No. 109-87, § 6, 4-7-87) 
Sec. 19-591. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVIII. - FLEA MARKETS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 113-98, adopted July 21, 1998, amended Art. VIII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly Art. VIII contained §§ 19-595-19-599 which derived from Ord. No. 119-85, adopted Dec. 3, 1985. 
Cross reference- Licenses and taxation, Ch. 14; secondhand goods and dealers, Ch. 25. 

Sec. 19-592. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended: 
    Articles. Secondhand clothing items; produce grown by the vendor or his/her immediate family; bric-a-brac and crafts made by the vendor or his/her immediate family; art work and paintings painted by the vendor or his/her immediate family; heat applied and screen printed items printed by the vendor or his/her immediate family; collectibles, including coins, toys, baseball cards, stamps, match box cars, etc.; used housewares such as cookware, dishes, lamps and other small items; used household goods such as furniture, antiques, appliances, and other large items for the home; certain approved food items. 
    City. City of Opelika. 
    Flea market. An out-of-doors market where articles, as defined herein, are sold to the public. 
    Municipal parking area. The municipally owned parking area along South Railroad Avenue bounded on the east by the Sixth Street Bridge and on the west by South 7th Street. 
(Ord. No. 113-98, § 1, 7-21-98; Ord. No. 113-06, § 1, 5-2-06) 
Sec. 19-593. - Name of the flea market. 
    The name of the flea market as defined in this article shall be "The Opelika Flea Market." 
(Ord. No. 113-98, § 1, 7-21-98) 
Sec. 19-594. - Use of municipal parking area. 
(a)  Use of public parking area. The municipal parking area, as defined in Section 19-592, shall be used exclusively for public parking on the following days of each week: Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday except for the first Saturday of each month. 
(b)  Use for flea market. The municipal parking area, as defined in Section 19-592, shall be opened to the public as a flea market between the hours of 6:30 a.m. and 11:30 a.m. on the first Saturday of each month. Vendors shall be allowed access to the designated area from 6:00 a.m. to 6:30 a.m. to set up and display their merchandise and from 11:30 a.m. to 12:00 noon to remove their merchandise and cleanup the area. No vehicles will be allowed to park in the designated flea market area except for loading and unloading between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 6:30 a.m. and between the hours of 11:30 a.m. and 12:00 noon. Vendors shall be permitted to park their vehicles in the parking area along South Railroad Avenue between South 7th Street and South 8th Street. All other municipal parking areas not being used for the flea market shall be opened to the public for parking on Saturdays. The city may close the flea market on a particular Saturday if that day coincides or conflicts with another scheduled event such as an arts and crafts festival. 
(Ord. No. 113-98, § 1, 7-21-98; Ord. No. 113-06, § 2, 5-2-06; Ord. No. 121-06, § 1, 1-20-06; Ord. No. 118-12, § 1, 10-2-12) 
Sec. 19-595. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 118-12, § 1, adopted October 2, 2012, repealed § 19-595, which pertained to committee appointed by mayor and derived from Ord. No. 113-98, § 1, 7-21-98. 
Sec. 19-596. - Permit required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall sell or offer for sale at any flea market from the public parking area any articles without first obtaining a permit therefor. Applications for permits shall be made to the revenue department. The price of the permit shall be seven dollars ($7.00) for each Saturday or twenty-one dollars ($21.00) for each quarter (three (3) days). Permits may be obtained at the revenue department at City Hall each Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. until 4:00 p.m., except on holidays. 
(Ord. No. 113-98, § 1, 7-21-98; Ord. No. 119-98, § 1, 9-15-98; Ord. No. 113-06, § 3, 5-2-06; Ord. No. 118-12, § 1, 10-2-12) 
Sec. 19-597. - Disposal of trash and unsold merchandise. 
    No trash or unsold merchandise shall be left in the market area by vendors or otherwise littered inside the city limits of the City of Opelika. All trash may be deposited inside trash receptacles provided by the city in the market area. Cardboard boxes and such shall be broken down flat before depositing said boxes in trash receptacles. Otherwise, all trash must be transported to other normally acceptable trash depositories. 
(Ord. No. 113-98, § 1, 7-21-98) 
Sec. 19-598. - Display of merchandise. 
    All merchandise offered for sale at the flea market must be displayed on table(s) and/or rack(s). 
(Ord. No. 113-98, § 1, 7-21-98) 
Sec. 19-599. - Responsibilities of the vendors. 
    Vendors shall be responsible for the following: 
(1)  Payment of any sales tax due to the City of Opelika, the State of Alabama or Lee County, Alabama. 
(2)  Obtaining temporary health permits from the Lee County Health Department as required for the selling of food products. 
(3)  Disposal of trash or unsold merchandise per section 19-597. 
(Ord. No. 113-98, § 1, 7-21-98) 
Sec. 19-600. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person convicted of violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a violation and shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  First violation: A fine of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(2)  Second violation: A fine of twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(3)  Third violation: A fine of thirty dollars ($30.00). 
(4)  Fourth or subsequent violation: A fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisonment of not more than thirty (30) days, or both such fine and imprisonment at the discretion of the court trying the case. In addition, the city shall have the right to suspend any permit issued to any person for any violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 113-98, § 1, 7-21-98) 
Secs. 19-601-19-624. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIX. - REGULATIONS FOR DISPLAY OF VEHICLES, MOTORIZED EQUIPMENT, BOATS, TRAILERS, RECREATIONAL VEHICLES AND CAMPERS 

Sec. 19-625. - Unlawful display. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park for display upon public right-of-way or other public property, or any vacant lot or parcel of real property or any other private property any motor vehicle, rebuildable salvage vehicle, motorized equipment, boat, trailer, recreational vehicle or camper (collectively called "vehicle" or "vehicles") having displayed thereon any writing indicating such vehicle is for sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, tenant or person in charge of premises to display for sale upon such premises, or permit the same to be done, of any vehicle not owned by said owner, tenant or person in charge. 
    The provisions of this section shall not apply to a vehicle parked off the public right-of-way at a single-family residence if the vehicle is owned and registered to the owner or occupant of the single-family residence. No more than two (2) vehicles shall be offered for sale in this manner at any given time. No more than four (4) vehicles shall be offered for sale in this manner during a twelve-month period. 
    In addition to the penalties provided herein, any vehicle found to be parked on public right-of-way or public property in violation of this section may be towed away and impounded at the owner's expense. 
(Ord. No. 108-09, § 1, 6-16-09) 
Sec. 19-626. - Exemption clause. 
    Neither this article nor any provision thereof shall not apply to any person properly licensed to engage in the business of selling motor vehicles and selling only at the location designated upon such license. 
(Ord. No. 108-09, § 1, 6-16-09) 
Sec. 19-627. - Penalties. 
    Any person convicted of violating any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine in an amount not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment of not more than six (6) months, or both such fine and imprisonment at the discretion of the court trying the case. 
(Ord. No. 108-09, § 1, 6-16-09) 
Sec. 19-628. - Each violation a separate offense. 
    Each day of violation of this article is a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 108-09, § 1, 6-16-09) 
Chapter 20 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 20-1-20-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RECREATION BOARD[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-16 et seq. 

Sec. 20-16. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a recreation board. 
(Code 1964, § 18-2) 
State Law reference- Power of city to create recreation board, Code of Ala., § 11-86-1. 
Sec. 20-17. - Members. 
    The recreation board shall consist of five (5) members who shall serve without compensation. The members of such board shall be selected and appointed by the governing body for terms of five (5) years each. Vacancies in unexpired terms shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments. 
(Code 1964, §§ 18-2, 18-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 11-86-2. 
Sec. 20-18. - Officers. 
    The recreation board shall elect from its membership a chairman and a secretary and such other officers as it deems necessary. Such officers shall serve at the pleasure of the board. 
(Code 1964, § 18-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 11-86-2. 
Sec. 20-19. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The recreation board shall be responsible for the direction, supervision and promotion of such recreation programs as will contribute to the general welfare of the residents of the city. The board shall have control over all lands, buildings, equipment and other facilities assigned for recreational purposes to the board by the governing body or purchased or leased by it from funds provided by the governing body. The board shall cooperate with other local agencies and state and federal agencies for the purpose of maintaining and improving recreational services and facilities for the city. The board shall have power to accept financial and other aid and grants from any public or private agency. 
(Code 1964, §§ 18-2, 18-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 11-86-3. 
Sec. 20-20. - Control of activities relating to parks and recreation. 
    Except as otherwise specified in this chapter, the operation and control of all activities relating to parks and recreation of the city shall be exercised by the recreation board. 
(Code 1964, § 18-1) 
Sec. 20-21. - Budget. 
    The recreation board is empowered and directed to set up its own budget of operations and expenses, subject to the approval of the governing body of the city, which shall have full power to revise the budget fixed by the board, at any time, to the extent that such budget constitutes an appropriation for the payment of any money out of the general or other funds of the city, and such funds shall be paid only on the order of the governing body and shall be paid by the city treasurer. 
(Code 1964, § 18-5) 
Sec. 20-22. - Participation in activities by other governmental units. 
    The recreation board may, with the approval of the governing body, invite the participation in the operation and upkeep of any of its parks and recreation areas of the county or other governmental units upon such terms as may be agreed upon between the city and county or other governmental unit. 
(Code 1964, § 18-8) 
Sec. 20-23. - Director of recreation and staff. 
    The recreation board may employ a municipal director of recreation to be its executive officer. The director, with the approval of the board, shall employ such staff as may be necessary to effect the recreation program determined by the board. The salaries of the director and the staff shall be fixed by the board. The tenure of the director and the staff shall be at the pleasure of the board. Traveling and other expenses of the director and the staff while in performance of their duties shall be provided for by the board. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala., § 11-86-4. 
Sec. 20-24. - Rules. 
    The recreation board shall adopt rules and regulations covering the procedures of the board and the use of lands, buildings, equipment and other facilities under its jurisdiction, including fees for the use of such lands, buildings, equipment and facilities. The board may provide for the suspension of the right of persons to use lands, buildings, equipment and other facilities under its jurisdiction for the violation of and such rules. 
(Code 1964, § 18-3) 
Secs. 20-25-20-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOG PARKS 

Sec. 20-51. - Purpose and intent. 
    The city is empowered to establish one (1) or more off-leash dog parks within the public parks of the City for the purpose of allowing the off-leash exercise of dogs, provided that any dog within such park must be under the control of an owner or handler who is competent and knowledgeable relating to the behavior of each such dog owned. The city council finds and declares that the purpose of this article is to promote the public peace, morals, health, safety and general welfare of persons and property and property in the city by regulating the activity of those bringing dogs to city dog parks. 
(Ord. No. 005-18, § 1, 3-6-18) 
Sec. 20-52. - Definitions. 
    Unless it is apparent from the context that another meaning is intended the following words when used herein shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section. 
    Aggression or aggressive behavior shall include, but is not limited to, the following behaviors: snapping, snarling, lunging, ferocious growling and/or barking and biting. 
    City means City of Opelika. 
    Dangerous dog shall have the same meaning as in section 4-2. 
    Dog means domestic dog, canis familiaris. 
    Dog owner or owner is defined as any person or legal entity owning, possessing, harboring, keeping or having custody or control of a dog. In the case of a dog owned by a minor, the term "dog owner" includes the parents or person in local parentis with custody of said minor. 
    Dog park or park shall refer to any city property that has been designated by the city or by the Opelika Parks and Recreation Department as an area where the public can recreate with their dogs, off leash, and within an enclosed space. 
    Handler shall mean the person who brought the dog to the park, and may include the dog's owner. 
    Large dog shall mean a dog weighing thirty (30) pounds or more. 
    Park staff shall include city police officer, animal control officer, employee of the parks and recreation department or any city employee authorized to enforce the provisions of this article. For the purposes of this article, park staff shall include dog park volunteers. 
    Small dog shall mean a dog weighing less than thirty (30) pounds. 
    Vicious dog shall have the same meaning as in section 4-9. 
    Visual control shall be defined as an owner being within seventy-five (75) feet of the dog at issue, able to control or recall the dog at all times and preventing the dog from becoming involved in any altercation with other dogs or people. 
    Voice control shall be defined to include dogs that immediately come to their handler when so commanded by their handler. 
(Ord. No. 005-18, § 1, 3-6-18) 
Sec. 20-53. - Dog park regulations. 
    The following regulations shall apply for all dog parks: 
(1)  Dog owners and/or handlers are legally responsible for their dogs and any injuries and/or damage caused by them. 
(2)  All dogs must have current licenses and required vaccinations and must wear a flat collar with a visible rabies tag. 
(3)  Certified service dogs of any size are allowed in any part of the park. 
(4)  Puppies under four (4) months old are not permitted inside the park. This rule is for the health and safety of the puppy. 
(5)  Dogs weighing less than thirty (30) pounds shall only be allowed in the area designated for small dogs and dogs weighing thirty (30) pounds or more shall only be allowed in the area designated for large dogs. 
(6)  Dogs in heat, pregnant or lactating dogs are not permitted inside the park. 
(7)  Dogs showing aggression toward people or other animals shall be immediately removed from the park by the owner or the handler. Dogs known to park staff to exhibit aggressive behaviors are not permitted within the park. 
(8)  Dogs that have been declared dangerous or vicious by any jurisdiction are not permitted inside the park. 
(9)  Dogs must be on a leash when entering and exiting the dog park, including within the parking lot. 
(10)  Digging is not permitted anywhere in the park. Owners or handlers are responsible to fill any holes dug by their dog. 
(11)  Dogs must not be left in a vehicle without their owner or handler at any time. 
(12)  Abandonment of dogs is prohibited. 
(13)  Handlers must be at least thirteen (13) years of age. Visitors under thirteen (13) are not permitted in the park without a supervising adult. 
(14)  Handlers may not bring more than two (2) dogs at any one time into the dog park. 
(15)  Handlers must stay within the park and supervise their dogs at all times and may not leave their dogs in the park unattended at any time. 
(16)  Handlers must keep close visual contact with their dogs and be aware of their actions at all times. 
(17)  Handlers must have one leash in their possession for every dog they bring to the park. 
(18)  Handlers must remove and properly dispose of all dog waste. 
(19)  All dogs using the park shall be free from contagious or infectious diseases, be parasite free, both externally and internally, and have no visible wounds or injuries. 
(20)  Smoking is prohibited within any dog park. 
(21)  The following items are prohibited in the dog park: 
a.  Food and drink except bottled water and water for the dog. 
b.  Glass bottles and similar breakable containers. 
c.  Alcoholic beverages. 
(22)  Owners and handlers must abide by all rules posted by the city at any dog park. Owners and handlers are charged with the responsibility of familiarizing themselves with all posted city park rules. 
(Ord. No. 005-18, § 1, 3-6-18) 
Sec. 20-54. - Liability. 
(a)  Owners and handlers are responsible for and liable for all injuries and damages caused by their dogs. 
(b)  Use of any city dog park shall constitute implied consent of a dog owner or handler to all conditions of this article and shall constitute a waiver of liability to the city. As such, owners and handlers agree to protect, indemnity, defend and hold harmless the city for any injury or damage caused by or to their dogs during any time that said dog is at a dog park facility. 
(c)  All persons and dogs enter and use the dog park at their own risk. 
(Ord. No. 005-18, § 1, 3-6-18) 
Sec. 20-55. - Enforcement. 
    Any owner or handler that violates any provision of this article, or who permits any dog to be in violation of any provision of this article, may be ordered by park staff or animal control officer to remove the dog from the park. Any handler who fails to immediately remove a dog following an order to do so shall be subject to the provisions of section 20-56. Any person found to be in violation of any provision of this article is subject to removal from the facility and may be prohibited from future use of city dog parks. 
(Ord. No. 005-18, § 1, 3-6-18) 
Sec. 20-56. - Penalties. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b), any person violating any provision of this article upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and by imprisonment of not more than thirty (30) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment and also cost of court for each offense. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the above, if any owner or handler brings a dog to the park that the owner or handler knows or should reasonably have known has been declared dangerous or vicious in any jurisdiction, and that dog due to its aggressive behavior, causes an injury to or death of another dog or person, the owner or handler of the dog shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment of not more than six (6) months or by both such fine and imprisonment and also cost of court for each offense. 
(c)  Any violation of the provisions of this article shall constitute a nuisance and may be abated by the city through civil process by means of a restraining order, preliminary or permanent injunction or any other manner provided by law for the abatement of such nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 005-18, § 1, 3-6-18) 
Chapter 21 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Keeping of horses or cattle near certain buildings, § 4-11; keeping of fowl near certain buildings, § 4-12; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; historic preservation, Ch. 11.5; housing code, § 12-16 et seq.; mobile homes, mobile home parks, trailers and trailer courts, Ch. 15. 
State Law reference- Municipal planning generally, Code of Ala., § 11-52-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Townhouse development ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect Ordinance Number 109-79, adopted by the governing body on June 19, 1979, and such ordinance is hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Secs. 21-2-21-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-16 et seq. 

Sec. 21-16. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a planning commission. 
(Code 1964, § 21-1) 
State Law reference- Planning commission authorized, Code of Ala., § 11-52-2. 
Sec. 21-17. - Membership. 
    The planning commission shall consist of nine (9) members: The mayor, one of the administrative officials of the municipality selected by the mayor, a member of the board of commissioners to be selected by it as a member ex officio and six (6) persons who shall be appointed by the mayor. The terms of ex officio members shall correspond to their respective official tenures, except the term of the administrative official selected by the mayor shall terminate with the term of the mayor selecting him. The term of each appointed member shall be six (6) years or until his successor takes office. Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of term shall be filled for the unexpired term of the mayor in the case of members selected or appointed by him; by the city commission in case of the member selected by it. The commission shall elect its chairman from among the appointed members and create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of office of the chairman shall be one year, with eligibility for re-election. 
(Code 1964, § 21-1) 
State Law reference- Members of planning commission, Code of Ala., § 11-52-3. 
Sec. 21-18. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The planning commission is authorized and empowered to make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the city, including any areas outside its boundaries which, in the commission's judgment, bear relation to the planning of such municipality. Such plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts and descriptive matter, shall show the commission's recommendations for the development of such territory, including, among other things, the general location, character and extent of streets, viaducts, subways, bridges, waterways, waterfronts, boulevards, parkways, playgrounds, squares, parks, aviation fields and other public ways, grounds and open spaces, the general location of public buildings and other public property, and the general location and extent of public utilities and terminals, whether publicly or privately owned or operated, for water, light, sanitation, transportation, communication, power and other purposes; also the removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, vacating, abandonment, change of use or extension of any of the foregoing ways, grounds, open spaces, buildings, property, utilities or terminals; as well as a zoning plan for the control of the height, area, bulk, location and use of the buildings and premises. As the work of making the whole master plan progresses, such commission may, from time to time, adopt and publish a part thereof, any such part to cover one or more major sections or divisions of the municipality, or one or more of the aforesaid or other functional matters to be included in the plan. 
(b)  The commission is hereby authorized and empowered to exercise all powers and do all things authorized to such commission by the laws of this state as it may deem necessary for its work. The commission is also authorized and empowered to exercise all powers and to do all things authorized to such commission by the laws of the state, and to exercise such control as is authorized under the applicable state law with reference to subdivision of unimproved property within five (5) miles of the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 21-2) 
State Law reference- Functions of planning commission, Code of Ala., § 11-52-6 et seq.; extra-territorial jurisdiction, Code of Ala., § 11-52-5. 
Chapter 22 - POLICE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---
